John, the son of Zechariah and Elizabeth, grew up and became a prophet. He lived in the wilderness, ate wild honey and locusts, and wore clothes made from camel hair.
Many people came out to the wilderness to listen to John. He preached to them, saying, “Repent, for the kingdom of God is near!”
When people heard John’s message, many of them repented from their sins, and John baptized them. Many religious leaders also came to be baptized by John, but they did not repent or confess their sins.
John said to the religious leaders, “You poisonous snakes! Repent and change your behavior. Every tree that does not bear good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.” John fulfilled what the prophets said, “See, I send my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way.”
Some Jews asked John if he was the Messiah. John replied, “I am not the Messiah, but there is someone coming after me. He is so great that I am not even worthy to untie his sandals.”
The next day, Jesus came to be baptized by John. When John saw him, he said, “Look! There is the Lamb of God who will take away the sin of the world.”
John said to Jesus, “I am not worthy to baptize you. You should baptize me instead.” But Jesus said, “You should baptize me, because it is the right thing to do.” So John baptized him, even though Jesus had never sinned.
When Jesus came up out of the water after being baptized, the Spirit of God appeared in the form of a dove and came down and rested on him. At the same time, God’s voice spoke from heaven, saying, “You are my Son whom I love, and I am very pleased with you.”
God had told John, “The Holy Spirit will come down and rest on someone you baptize. That person is the Son of God.” There is only one God. But when John baptized Jesus, he heard God the Father speak, saw God the Son, who is Jesus, and he saw the Holy Spirit.

24. Jean Baptise Jésus





Jean, le fils de Zacharie et d’Elisabeth grandit et devint un prophète. Il habitait dans le désert, mangeait du miel sauvage et des sauterelles, et portait des vêtements faits de poils de chameaux.
Beaucoup de gens vinrent dans le désert pour écouter Jean. Il prêchait en leur disant: “Repentez-vous, car le Royaume de Dieu est proche.”
Quand les gens entendirent le message de Jean, beaucoup d’entre eux se repentirent de leurs péchés et Jean les baptisa. Beaucoup de chefs religieux voulurent être baptisés sans s’être repentis et sans avoir confessé leurs péchés.
Jean dit qux leaders religieux: “Vous, races de vipères venimeuses! Repentez-vous et changez votre comportement. Chaque arbre qui ne produit pas de bons fruits sera coupé et jeté au feu.” Jean accomplit ce que les prophètes avaient dit: “Voici, j’envoie mon messager qui vous préparera votre chemin.”
Quelques Juifs demandèrent à Jean s’il était le Messie. Jean répondit: “Je ne suis pas le Messie, mais il y a quelqu’un qui viendra après moi. Il est si grand que je ne suis même pas digne de dénouer les lacets de ses chaussures.”
Le lendemain, Jésus vint pour que Jean le baptise. Quand Jean le vit, Il dit: “Voici l’Agneau de Dieu qui enlève le péché du monde.”
Jean dit à Jésus: “Je ne suis pas digne de te baptiser. C’est moi qui ai besoin d’être baptisé par toi” Mais Jésus dit: “Tu dois me baptiser, car c’est la chose juste à faire.” Alors Jean le baptisa, bien que Jésus n’avait jamais péché.
Quand Jésus sortit de l’eau après avoir été baptisé, l’Esprit de Dieu apparut sous la forme d’une colombe et descendit sur lui. Aussitôt la voix de Dieu venant du ciel dit: “Tu es mon Fils bien-aimé, en qui j’ai mis toute mon affection et tu fais toute ma joie.”
Dieu avait dit à Jean: “Le Saint-Esprit descendra sur quelqu’un que tu baptiseras ,cette personne est le fils de Dieu.” Il n’existe qu’un seul Dieu. Mais quand Jean baptisa Jésus, il entendit Dieu le Père parler, il vit Dieu le Fils qui est Jésus, et il vit Dieu le Saint-Esprit.

007 Abraham and Isaac


Many years later, Sarah died in the land of Canaan. She was 127 years old. So Abraham bought a nearby piece of land with a cave on it. He buried Sarah there in the land of Canaan. Abraham wept and mourned for her.
Abraham did not want Isaac to marry a Canaanite woman. So he ordered his chief servant to travel to Haran city where Abraham’s relatives lived, to get a wife for Isaac.
Abraham made his servant promise not to take Isaac to live in Haran, but to bring a woman to become Isaac’s wife back to the land of Canaan because God promised Abraham to give this land of Canaan to his descendants.
So the servant took ten camels loaded with supplies and gifts and traveled to the far away city where Abraham's family had come from. He made the camels rest near the well outside the city just as the women were coming to get water.
The servant prayed, “Lord God, when I say to a young woman, ‘May I have a drink?’ If she says, ‘Drink and I will get water for your camels, too.’ I will know that she is the woman you have chosen to be a wife for Isaac.”
Before he finished praying, a beautiful young woman arrived there, carrying a jar on her shoulder. She went to the edge of the well, filled her jar with water, and then came back to where the servant was standing.
Abraham's servant immediately ran to meet her, and said, "Please give me a little water from your jar."
She gave him water and then said, "I will get water for your camels, too!"
Abraham’s servant talked with the young woman. He learned that she was the daughter of one of Abraham’s relatives.
Then the servant worshiped the Lord for helping him to find this woman.
Rebekah ran home and told her family about all that had happened.
Her brother Laban then went to the well. He invited Abraham's servant and the men who came with him to spend the night at his house.
Then the servant told Laban’s whole family, "I am Abraham's servant. He made me solemnly promise to get a wife for his son, Isaac, from his family, his own clan. As I prayed for God’s guidance at the well today, He brought Rebekah to give us a drink.”
Rebekah’s father and brother answered, “This is the Lord’s will. Take Rebekah and let her be Isaac’s wife.”
So the next day, Rebekah left with Abraham’s servant to go to Isaac in Canaan.
Thus, Rebekah became Isaac’s wife. Isaac loved Rebekah, and so he was comforted after the loss of his mother.

There once was a monkey who was friendly with a turtle. Their homes were next to each other. The monkey lived in a tree, while the turtle lived on the edge of the river.
Mr. Tani’s garden expanded across the other side. There one could find ripe vegetables and fresh fruits. The monkey wanted to enjoy these fruits, but he could not cross the river.
While the monkey was thinking of how he could get there, his friend asked, “What are you thinking about, friend?”

“Really? Where is that?” asked the turtle.

                                “Over there,” the turtle pointed to Mr. Tani’s garden. “But I can’t swim. Would you like to carry me across?”

                                “Okay, get on my back and we will go right now,” answered the turtle.
The monkey quickly sat on the back of the turtle and they crossed the river. Arriving on the other side, the monkey said to the turtle, “Stand guard so that if Mr. Tani comes we can escape quickly. Later I will bring some fruit for you.”
The turtle agreed and the monkey quickly climbed the tree. But the monkey was naughty and greedy and forgot the turtle was down there watching. He ate the fruit all by himself until he was full. He only threw down the parts he could not eat and the rotten fruit.
Suddenly the turtle became aware that he was just being deceived by the monkey and he became angry. “Just wait for my revenge,” he muttered while he looked for a way to pay back the monkey.
While the monkey was still enjoying his private feast, he was startled by the voice of his companion. “Mr. Tani is coming! Let’s run before he gets here!” shouted the turtle as he ran. The startled monkey ran at top speed. He approached the turtle who was waiting for him at the edge of the river.
The monkey jumped on the turtle's back and they immediately swam toward the other side. Then in the middle of the river the turtle crashed himself into a big rock and pretended to be shaky. As a result, the turtle fell and drifted off in the strong river current. “Help! Help...” screamed the monkey as he started to sink because he could not swim.
Fortunately there was a strong current that tossed the monkey up on the river shore. The monkey vomited and vomited because he had swallowed so much water. All the fruit he had eaten also came out. The monkey sobbed and cried while lying limp on the ground. He realized what he had done and regretted deceiving his good friend.
When the turtle appeared, the monkey asked for his forgiveness while continuing to sob and cry. “Forgive me, my friend. I am very sorry I slighted you. I promise I will not be greedy or deceive you ever again.”
“Okay, we will forgive each other. Actually I didn’t mean to hurt you. Maybe this can be a lesson for both of us,” said the turtle while hugging the monkey.

Les pesticides : règles d'utilisation



Les pesticides : règles d'utilisation





Ce qu'il ne faut pas faire
Il ne faut jamais se procurer (achat, distribution) des produits dans des emballages endommagés.
Il ne faut jamais ré-emballer ou transvaser les produits dans des récipients autres que ceux d'origine (sachets, bouteilles, bidons, tonnelets, etc.)
Il ne faut jamais prélever et mélanger les produits avec des mains non protégées.
Il ne faut pas verser le produit sur les pieds lors du remplissage de l'appareil, mais plutôt utiliser un entonnoir.
Il ne faut pas utiliser les vieux emballages à d'autres fins (collecte d'eau, conservation des denrées, etc.).
Il ne faut pas utiliser des appareils défectueux lors de l'épandage des pesticides.
Il ne faut jamais traiter contre le sens du vent.
Il ne faut pas traiter sous la pluie.
Il ne faut pas manger, boire ou fumer pendant la manipulation des produits.
Il ne faut pas polluer l'environnement avec les produits (lacs, ruisseaux, forêts, etc.).
Ce qu'il faut faire
Il faut conserver les pesticides dans un local sûr et verrouillé, à l'écart des denrées alimentaires et loin de la portée des enfants.
Il faut ranger chaque type de produit dans le bon endroit.
Il faut lire attentivement les indications marquées sur l'étiquette avant toute utilisation du produit.
Il faut se munir d'un équipement adéquat pour toute manipulation de pesticides (chapeau, gants, combinaison, chaussures fermées, etc.).
Il faut faire très attention en manipulant le concentré ou le produit, surtout lors du remplissage des appareils de pulvérisation.
Il faut tenir la lance du pulvérisateur à bonne distance de la cible, de façon à avoir un traitement uniforme.
Il faut enterrer les emballages de produits vides dans un coin du terrain.
Il faut rincer les outils après l'usage (appareil, seau, entonnoir, gobelet, etc.).
Il faut se laver à l'eau et au savon après avoir manié les produits et changer de tenue avant de manger, boire ou fumer.
Il faut voir un médecin en cas d'empoisonnement (indigestion, inhalation, contact, etc.) avec un échantillon du produit.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Everyone must be responsible and take the right steps to protect themselves and those around them.

101 The Angel Gabriel Visits Mary


In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to speak to a virgin, named Mary, who was engaged to be married to a man named Joseph. They lived in a town called Nazareth.
The angel said to Mary, “Greetings! The Lord is with you and has shown great kindness to you!”
Mary felt very troubled when she heard his greeting. She wondered what the angel meant by these words.
Then the angel said, “Don’t be afraid, Mary; for God is very pleased with you!”
“You will become pregnant and give birth to a son, and you must name him Jesus.
He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High God. The Lord God will make him a king as his ancestor David was. He will rule forever!”
Then Mary asked the angel, “How can this happen, since I am a virgin?”
The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come to you and the power of God will cover you. So the baby will be holy and be called the Son of God.”
Then Mary said, “All right, I am the Lord’s servant, so let what you have said about me happen!” Then the angel left her.
Very soon after that, Mary got ready and went to visit her cousin, Elizabeth. As soon as Elizabeth heard Mary greet her, the baby leaped inside Elizabeth’s womb.
Immediately the Holy Spirit guided Elizabeth to start praising God. She exclaimed loudly to Mary, “God has blessed you more than he has blessed other women, and he has blessed the baby you will bear!”
Then Mary praised God saying, “Oh, how I praise the Lord! All people will say that God has blessed me because of the great things that God, the Powerful One, has done for me.”
Mary visited with Elizabeth for about three months. Then she returned to her home.
Before they had lived together as husband and wife, Joseph found out that Mary was pregnant. Joseph did not want to shame her in front of other people, so he decided to quietly drop his plans to marry her.
While he was seriously considering this, an angel sent from God surprised him in a dream and said, “Do not be afraid to marry Mary. What has been conceived in her is there by the Holy Spirit.
She will have a son. Because he will save his people from their sins, name him ‘Jesus’.”
All this took place to make come true what the Lord told the prophet Isaiah to write long ago, “A virgin will become pregnant and will give birth to a son. They will call him Immanuel, which means ‘God is with us’.”
When Joseph got up from sleep, he did what the angel had commanded him to do. He began to live with Mary as his wife. But he did not sleep with her until she had given birth to a son.

24. John Baptizes Jesus


John, the son of Zechariah and Elizabeth, grew up and became a prophet. He lived in the wilderness, ate wild honey and locusts, and wore clothes made from camel hair.
Many people came out to the wilderness to listen to John. He preached to them, saying, “Repent, for the kingdom of God is near!”
When people heard John’s message, many of them repented from their sins, and John baptized them. Many religious leaders also came to be baptized by John, but they did not repent or confess their sins.
John said to the religious leaders, “You poisonous snakes! Repent and change your behavior. Every tree that does not bear good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.” John fulfilled what the prophets said, “See, I send my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way.”
Some Jews asked John if he was the Messiah. John replied, “I am not the Messiah, but there is someone coming after me. He is so great that I am not even worthy to untie his sandals.”
The next day, Jesus came to be baptized by John. When John saw him, he said, “Look! There is the Lamb of God who will take away the sin of the world.”
John said to Jesus, “I am not worthy to baptize you. You should baptize me instead.” But Jesus said, “You should baptize me, because it is the right thing to do.” So John baptized him, even though Jesus had never sinned.
When Jesus came up out of the water after being baptized, the Spirit of God appeared in the form of a dove and came down and rested on him. At the same time, God’s voice spoke from heaven, saying, “You are my Son whom I love, and I am very pleased with you.”
God had told John, “The Holy Spirit will come down and rest on someone you baptize. That person is the Son of God.” There is only one God. But when John baptized Jesus, he heard God the Father speak, saw God the Son, who is Jesus, and he saw the Holy Spirit.

24. Jean Baptise Jésus


Jean, le fils de Zacharie et d’Elisabeth grandit et devint un prophète. Il habitait dans le désert, mangeait du miel sauvage et des sauterelles, et portait des vêtements faits de poils de chameaux.
Beaucoup de gens vinrent dans le désert pour écouter Jean. Il prêchait en leur disant: “Repentez-vous, car le Royaume de Dieu est proche.”
Quand les gens entendirent le message de Jean, beaucoup d’entre eux se repentirent de leurs péchés et Jean les baptisa. Beaucoup de chefs religieux voulurent être baptisés sans s’être repentis et sans avoir confessé leurs péchés.
Jean dit qux leaders religieux: “Vous, races de vipères venimeuses! Repentez-vous et changez votre comportement. Chaque arbre qui ne produit pas de bons fruits sera coupé et jeté au feu.” Jean accomplit ce que les prophètes avaient dit: “Voici, j’envoie mon messager qui vous préparera votre chemin.”
Quelques Juifs demandèrent à Jean s’il était le Messie. Jean répondit: “Je ne suis pas le Messie, mais il y a quelqu’un qui viendra après moi. Il est si grand que je ne suis même pas digne de dénouer les lacets de ses chaussures.”
Le lendemain, Jésus vint pour que Jean le baptise. Quand Jean le vit, Il dit: “Voici l’Agneau de Dieu qui enlève le péché du monde.”
Jean dit à Jésus: “Je ne suis pas digne de te baptiser. C’est moi qui ai besoin d’être baptisé par toi” Mais Jésus dit: “Tu dois me baptiser, car c’est la chose juste à faire.” Alors Jean le baptisa, bien que Jésus n’avait jamais péché.
Quand Jésus sortit de l’eau après avoir été baptisé, l’Esprit de Dieu apparut sous la forme d’une colombe et descendit sur lui. Aussitôt la voix de Dieu venant du ciel dit: “Tu es mon Fils bien-aimé, en qui j’ai mis toute mon affection et tu fais toute ma joie.”
Dieu avait dit à Jean: “Le Saint-Esprit descendra sur quelqu’un que tu baptiseras ,cette personne est le fils de Dieu.” Il n’existe qu’un seul Dieu. Mais quand Jean baptisa Jésus, il entendit Dieu le Père parler, il vit Dieu le Fils qui est Jésus, et il vit Dieu le Saint-Esprit.

03. The Flood





03. The Flood


After a long time, many people were living in the world. They had become very wicked and violent. It became so bad that God decided to destroy the whole world with a huge flood.

But Noah found favor with God. He was a righteous man, living among wicked people. God told Noah about the flood He was planning to send. He told Noah to build a huge boat.
God told Noah to make the boat about 140 meters long, 23 meters wide, and 13.5 meters high. Noah was to build it with wood and to make three levels, many rooms, a roof, and a window. The boat would keep Noah, his family, and every kind of land animal safe during the flood.
Noah obeyed God. He and his three sons built the boat just the way God had told them. It took many years to build the boat, because it was so big. Noah warned the people about the flood that was coming and told them to turn to God, but they did not believe him.
God also commanded Noah and his family to gather enough food for themselves and the animals. When everything was ready, God told Noah it was time for him, his wife, his three sons, and their wives to get into the boat—eight people in all.
God sent a male and a female of every animal and bird to Noah sothey could go into the boat and be kept safe during the flood. God sent seven males and seven females of every type of animal that could be used for sacrifices. When they were all in the boat, God himself closed the door.
Then it began to rain, and rain, and rain. It rained for forty days and forty nights without stopping! Water also came gushing up out of the earth. Everything in the whole world was covered with water, even the highest mountains.
Everything that lived on the dry land died, except the people and animals that were in the boat. The boat floated on the water and kept everything inside the boat safe from drowning.
After the rains stopped, the boat floated on the water for five months, and during this time the water started going down. Then one day the boat rested on the top of a mountain, but the world was still covered with water. After three more months, the tops of the mountains were visible.
After forty more days, Noah sent out a bird called a raven to see if the water had dried up. The raven flew back and forth looking for dry land, but it could not find any.
Later Noah sent out a bird called a dove. But it also could not find any dry land, so it came back to Noah. A week later he sent the dove out again, and it came back with an olive branch in its beak! The water was going down, and the plants were growing again!
Noah waited another week and sent out the dove a third time. This time, it found a place to rest and did not come back. The water was drying up!
Two months later God said to Noah, “You and your family and all the animals may leave the boat now. Have many children and grandchildren and fill the earth.” So Noah and his family came out of the boat.
After Noah got off the boat, he built an altar and sacrificed some of each kind of animal that could be used for a sacrifice. God was happy with the sacrifice and blessed Noah and his family.
God said, “I promise I will never again curse the ground because of the evil things that people do, or destroy the world by causing a flood, even though people are sinful from the time they are children.”
God then made the first rainbow as a sign of his promise. Every time the rainbow appeared in the sky, God would remember what he promised and so would his people.

03. Le Déluge


Après bien des années, beaucoup d’hommes vivaient sur la terre. Ils étaient devenus très méchants et violents. La situation se dégrada au point où Dieu décida de détruire le monde avec un énorme déluge.
Mais Noé trouva grâce aux yeux de Dieu. C’était un homme juste qui vivait parmi un peuple méchant. Dieu dit à Noé qu’il allait détruire le monde par un grand déluge. Il lui dit de construire une grande arche.
Dieu dit à Noé de faire une arche en bois d’environ: 140 mètres de longueur, 23 mètres de largeur et 13,5 mètres de hauteur. Noé devait la construire en bois et faire 3 étages, beaucoup de pièces, un toit et une fenêtre. Ainsi, Noé, sa famille, et chaque espèce animale sera hors de danger dans l’arche, pendant le déluge.
Noé obéit à Dieu. Noé et ses trois fils bâtirent l’arche exactement comme Dieu leur avait demandé. Il leur fallut plusieurs années pour construire l’arche; tellement elle était grande! Noé avertit le peuple que le déluge allait arriver et leur dit de se tourner vers Dieu, mais ils ne le crurent point.
Dieu demanda à Noé et à sa famille de ramasser assez de nourriture pour eux-mêmes et les animaux. Quand tout fut prêt, Dieu dit à Noé qu’il était temps pour lui, sa femme, ses trois fils et leurs femmes, d’entrer dans l’arche. Ils étaient au total, huit personnes.
Dieu envoya un mâle et une femelle de chaque espèce animale à Noé, afin qu’ils entrent dans le bateau et soient hors de danger pendant le déluge. Dieu envoya sept mâles et sept femelles de chaque espèce animale qui pouvait être offerte en sacrifice. Quand ils furent tous dans l’arche, Dieu lui-même ferma la porte.
Puis il commença à pleuvoir sans cesse. Il plut pendant 40 jours et 40 nuits sans arrêt. L’eau jaillissait aussi de la terre. Tout sur la terre fut recouvert d’eau, même les plus hautes montagnes.
Tout ce qui vivait sur la terre sèche périt, à l’exception des hommes et des animaux qui étaient dans l’arche. L’arche flotta sur l’eau et préserva tous ceux qui étaient à l’intérieur.
Une fois que la pluie s’arrêta, l’arche flotta sur l’eau pendant cinq mois et ensuite l’eau commença à diminuer. Puis un jour, l’arche resta accroché au sommet d’une montagne car la terre était toujours couverte d’eau. Trois mois plus tard, les sommets des montagnes furent visibles.
Au bout de 40 autres jours, Noé lâcha un corbeau, pour voir si l’eau avait diminué. Le corbeau vola à la recherche de la terre sèche, mais il n’en trouva pas.

Plus tard, Noé lâcha un autre oiseau, une colombe. Mais la colombe non plus ne put trouver de terre sèche; par conséquent elle revint vers Noé. Une semaine plus tard, il renvoya la colombe, et elle revint avec une branche d’olivier dans son bec. L’eau diminuait et les plantes poussaient à nouveau!
Noé attendit encore une autre semaine et renvoya la colombe pour une troisième fois. Cette fois-ci, elle trouva un endroit pour se reposer et ne revint plus, pendant ce temps l’eau s’évaporait!
Deux mois plus tard, Dieu dit à Noé: “Toi, ta famille et tous les animaux, sortez de l’arche maintenant. Ayez beaucoup d’enfants et de petit-fils et remplissez la terre.” Alors Noé et sa famille sortirent de l’arche.
Une fois que Noé fut sorti, Il bâtit un autel et offrit à Dieu des animaux destinés au sacrifices. Dieu fut content du sacrifice et bénit Noé et sa famille.
Dieu dit: “Je promets de ne plus jamais maudire la terre à cause des mauvaises choses que font les hommes et je ne détruirai plus le monde par un déluge car l’homme est pécheur dès dès sa naissance.”

Alors Dieu créa le premier arc-en-ciel pour servir de signe à sa promesse. Toutes les fois que l’arc-en-ciel apparaitra dans le ciel, Dieu et son peuple se souviendront de sa promesse.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Le coronavirus, aussi appelé COVID-19, est un nouveau virus. Il a été signalé pour la première fois en Chine le 31 décembre 2019. Il a des symptômes semblables à ceux de la grippe et peut entraîner la mort dans certains cas graves. Il est répandu dans de nombreux pays dans le monde entier. L’origine de la maladie n’est pas encore connue.


Personne âgée

Personne cardiaque ou souffrant de maladie
Personnes vulnérables
Les personnes de tous âges, y compris les enfants, peuvent être infectées par ce nouveau virus. Les personnes âgées et les personnes souffrant de maladies préexistantes (comme l’asthme, le diabète, les maladies cardiaques, l’hypertension artérielle) semblent plus susceptibles de tomber gravement malades à cause de ce virus.

- Fatigue

Les symptômes
Les symptômes d'une infection au coronavirus ressemblent à ceux de la grippe : fièvre, toux sèche, douleurs musculaires, fatigue. Certains patients ont des douleurs, une congestion nasale, un écoulement nasal, des maux de gorge ou une diarrhée. Certaines personnes, bien qu’infectées, ne présentent aucun symptôme et se sentent bien. La plupart des personnes guérissent sans avoir besoin de traitement particulier.

Personne qui tousse
Transmission du coronavirus
Le COVID-19 est transmis par des personnes porteuses du virus. Quand un malade tousse ou éternue, il expulse des gouttelettes par le nez ou la bouche. Si une personne respire ces gouttelettes, elle peut être contaminée par le coronavirus. Si une personne touche un objet infecté par ces gouttelettes et si elle se touche ensuite les yeux, le nez ou la bouche, elle peut aussi être contaminée.




Comment se protéger ?
1. Eviter de se toucher les yeux, le nez, la bouche.

2. Se laver souvent les mains à l'eau courante et au savon. Ensuite les sécher avec une serviette propre.

3. Tousser et éternuer dans le creux de son bras.

5. Garder une distance d'au moins un mètre avec une personne qui tousse ou qui éternue.

6. Eviter de se serrer la main. Se saluer par un signe de tête ou une salutation verbale.

7. Eviter les rassemblements.

8. Limiter ses déplacements.

On the day that Jesus was raised from the dead, two of his disciples were going to a nearby town. As they walked, they talked about what had happened to Jesus. They had hoped that he was the Messiah, but then he was killed. Now the women said he was alive again. They did not know what to believe.
Jesus approached them and started walking with them, but they did not recognize him. He asked what they were talking about, and they told him about all the remarkable things that had happened concerning Jesus during the previous few days. They thought they were talking to a visitor who did not know what had happened in Jerusalem.
Then Jesus explained to them what God’s word said about the Messiah. He reminded them that the prophets said the Messiah would suffer and be killed, but would rise again on the third day. When they arrived at the town where the two men planned to stay, it was almost evening.
The two men invited Jesus to stay with them, so he did. When they were ready to eat the evening meal, Jesus picked up a loaf of bread, thanked God for it, and then broke it. Suddenly, they recognized that he was Jesus. But at that moment, he disappeared from their sight.
The two men said to each other, “That was Jesus! That is why our hearts were burning when he explained God’s word to us!” Immediately, they went back to Jerusalem. When they arrived, they told the disciples, “Jesus is alive! We have seen him!”
As the disciples were talking, Jesus suddenly appeared in the room with them and said, “Peace to you!” The disciples thought he was a ghost, but Jesus said, “Why are you afraid and doubting? Look at my hands and feet. Ghosts do not have bodies like I do.” To prove that he was not a ghost, he asked for something to eat. They gave him a piece of cooked fish, and he ate it.
Jesus said, “I told you that everything written about me in God’s word must be fulfilled.” Then he opened their minds so that they could understand God’s word. He said, “It was written long ago that the Messiah would suffer, die, and rise from the dead on the third day.”
“It was also written in the scriptures that my disciples will proclaim that everyone should repent in order to receive forgiveness for their sins. They will do this starting in Jerusalem, and then go to all people groups everywhere. You are witnesses of these things.”
During the next forty days, Jesus appeared to his disciples many times. Once, he even appeared to more than 500 people at the same time! He proved to his disciples in many ways that he was alive, and he taught them about the kingdom of God.
Jesus said to his disciples, “All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. So go, make disciples of all people groups by baptizing them in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, and by teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. Remember, I will be with you always.”
Forty days after Jesus rose from the dead, he told his disciples, “Stay in Jerusalem until my Father gives you power when the Holy Spirit comes on you.” Then Jesus went up to heaven, and a cloud hid him from their sight. Jesus sat down at the right hand of God to rule over all things.

At this time, Jesus had four disciples. Their names were Philip, Nathanael, Andrew and Simon Peter. Andrew and Simon Peter were brothers.
A few days after these disciples began following Jesus, there was a wedding celebration in the town of Cana. Jesus’ mother was there, and Jesus and his disciples had also been invited to the feast.
Before the feast was over, the wine supply was gone.
Jesus mother said to him, “They are out of wine.”
Jesus replied, “Why are you saying this to me? My time has not yet come.”
Jesus' mother then told the servants, “Do whatever he tells you.”
The Jews have rules about ritual washing, and for this purpose six stone water jars were there, each one large enough to hold between twenty and thirty gallons.
Jesus said to the servants, “Fill these jars with water.” The servants filled them to the top.
Then Jesus told them, “Now take some out and take it to the man in charge of the feast.” So the servants did as he told them.
The man in charge tasted the water and it had become wine, but he did not know where this wine had come from. The servants who had drawn out the water knew!
Then the man in charge of the feast spoke privately to the bridegroom. He told him, “Everyone else serves the best wine first.
Then, after the guests have drunk a lot, they serve the ordinary wine. But you have kept the best wine until now!”
Jesus performed this first miracle at Cana in Galilee. In this way, he revealed his glory, and his disciples believed in him.
After the wedding, Jesus and his mother, brothers, and disciples went to Capernaum and stayed there a few days.

108 Le mariage à Cana



108 Le mariage à Cana





Jésus a appelé quatre disciples à le suivre. Leurs noms sont : Philippe, Nathanaël, André, et Simon Pierre. André et Simon Pierre sont des frères.
Les disciples suivent Jésus depuis quelques jours quand il y a un mariage dans le village de Cana. Les mariés invitent aussi Jésus et ses disciples, ainsi que la mère de Jésus.
Pendant la fête, la réserve de vin s’épuise.
Alors la mère de Jésus lui dit : « Les gens n’ont plus de vin. Est-ce que tu peux faire quelque chose pour changer cela ? »
Jésus lui répond : « Pourquoi me dis-tu cela ? Ce n’est pas encore le moment pour moi de révéler que je suis le Messie, l’envoyé de Dieu. »
La mère de Jésus dit aux serviteurs : « Faites tout ce qu’il vous dira. ».
Il y a là six grands récipients de pierre. Les Juifs se servent de ces récipients pour leurs cérémonies religieuses. Dans chaque récipient, on peut mettre une centaine de litres.
Jésus dit aux serviteurs : « Remplissez ces récipients avec de l’eau. » Les serviteurs les remplissent jusqu’au bord.
Ensuite Jésus leur dit : « Maintenant, prenez de cette eau et apportez-la au responsable du repas de fête. » Les serviteurs font ce qu’il dit.
Quand le responsable goûte l’eau, elle est devenue du vin délicieux. Il ne sait pas d’où vient ce vin. Mais les serviteurs le savent.
Alors le responsable du repas appelle le marié et lui dit : « Tout le monde sert d’abord le bon vin.
Et quand les invités ont beaucoup bu, on sert du vin moins bon. Mais toi, tu as gardé le meilleur vin jusqu’à maintenant ! »
C’est là le premier signe extraordinaire que Jésus fait. Il montre ainsi sa gloire, et ses disciples croient en lui.
Après le mariage, Jésus quitte Cana et va à Capernaúm avec sa mère, ses frères et ses disciples. Ils y restent pendant quelques jours.

All of us went to the fun fair.
Father bought brother fancy glasses. Mother bought me a bright blue cap. The baby got sugar candy.
On the way home, a very strong wind came. It blew my cap away.
My cap got stuck on a branch of a big old tree.
I cried a lot. And I did not eat my dinner.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Abike was lying down on her mat. She was listening to her mother telling her one of her favourite stories.

The story was about the women of their village, who are known for making beautiful mats and baskets.

Abike's most precious gift was the sleeping mat her grandmother made for her 10th birthday.
When Abike got up, her mother wanted to put away the mat. "Not yet Ma, let's look at the colours and shapes together," Abike asked.

Abike named the colours of the rows, from top to bottom, "Pink, pink, green, green, blue, blue, pink, pink, green, green."

Can you see where the pattern changes on the mat?
Abike stretched out the mat. Most of the shapes were rectangles, with some squares as well.
"I know a quick way to work out how many shapes there are altogether," said Abike. "You don't count each shape, you only count the number of shapes in a row."

Do you know how Abike counts the shapes?
How many shapes are there altogether?
Abike had another smaller mat that she used to sit outside on the ground. This mat had only rectangles.

About how many of the rectangles is Abike covering with her body? ﻿About how many rectangles are not covered?
Can you use Abike's quick way to work out how many rectangles the mat has altogether?
One morning Abike went to visit her grandmother. At the well she saw women fetching water in buckets they were carrying on their heads.

She wondered how many litres of water each bucket holds.

What do you think?
Abike arrived at her grandmother's house. "What a lovely surprise Abike! Look at this new basket I made. Do you like it?" Grandma asked.

"I like the colours, but the shapes are too sharp and pointed," replied Abike.

How would you copy the pattern on the basket?
Are the shapes like a square or a rectangle or another shape?
On her way home, Abike lost the path. She wasn't sure where she was, so she sat down to rest under a tree.

Abike stared at the leaves dancing on the branches above. There were patterns of light and shade all around her. Soon she fell into a deep sleep.


When she woke up, she felt afraid. She wanted to be at home with her mother, resting on her mat.

Just then a small, blue bird landed in the tree. "Hello, don't worry, I can help you get home. Follow me," it chirped.

Abike was surprised to hear a bird talking.


Abike followed the bird easily until they came to a fork in the path. The path split into two different directions, one to the left and one to the right. Which path should she take?

Abike looked up. Was it possible? The bird had a piece of her mat in its beak!

It flew over the path on the right-hand side and dropped the piece of mat. Then the bird flew away.


Abike followed the path down the hill. She heard the laughter and singing of the people of her village.

Abike was happy to be home safely.


Abike's mother rolled out her mat and gave her a bowl of food to eat.

Abike began counting the squares just to make sure they were still all there. While she was counting she was sure she saw a piece of the mat that had been taken out and put back again.

So, she was not dreaming. The small, blue bird was real after all!
La journée d'Abike.original_text:
La journée d'Abike

Penelope Smith
Catherine Groenewald

La journée d'Abike





Abike était couchée sur sa natte en train d’écouter sa mère qui lui racontait l’une de ses histoires préférées. L’histoire parlait des femmes de leur village connues pour faire de jolies nattes et de jolis paniers.

Le cadeau le plus précieux qu’Abike avait reçu était la natte que sa grand-mère avait faite pour son dixième anniversaire.
Quand Abike se levait et que sa mère voulait ranger la natte, Abike lui disait : « Pas encore, maman, regardons ensemble les couleurs et les formes. »

Abike nommait les couleurs des lignes, de haut en bas : « Rose, rose, vert, vert, bleu, bleu, rose, rose, vert, vert. »

Peux-tu voir où change le dessin sur la natte ?
Abike étendit la natte. La plupart des formes étaient des rectangles, mais il y avait aussi quelques carrés. « Je connais une façon rapide de trouver combien de formes il y a au total », dit Abike. « Tu ne comptes pas chaque forme, mais tu ne comptes que le nombre de formes sur une ligne. »

Sais-tu comment Abike compte les formes ? Combien de formes y a-t-il au total ?
Abike avait une autre natte plus petite qu’elle utilisait pour s’asseoir dehors. Cette natte n’avait que des rectangles.

Combien de rectangles environ sont couverts par le corps d’Abike ? Combien de rectangles environ ne sont pas couverts ? Sais-tu utiliser la façon rapide d’Abike pour trouver le nombre total de rectangles sur la natte ?
Un matin Abike était allée visiter sa grand-mère. Au puits elle voyait des femmes en train de puiser de l’eau dans des seaux qu’elles portaient sur leurs têtes. Elle se demandait combien de litres d’eau chaque seau pouvait contenir.

Que penses-tu ?

Abike arriva à la maison de sa grand-mère.
« Quelle belle surprise Abike ! Regarde ce nouveau panier que j’ai fait. Est-ce que tu l’aimes ? » lui demanda la grand-mère.
« J’aime les couleurs, mais les formes sont trop aigües et trop pointues », répondit Abike.

Comment copierais-tu le dessin sur le panier ? Est-ce que les formes sont comme un carré ou un rectangle ? Sont-elles peut-être aussi d’une autre forme ?
En rentrant, Abike perdit son chemin. Elle n’était pas sûre de l’endroit où elle se trouvait. Elle s’assit donc sous un arbre pour se reposer.
Abike fixait son regard sur les feuilles qui étaient en train de danser sur les branches au-dessus d’elle. Il y avait des dessins faits de lumière et d’ombre tout autour d’elle. Puis elle s’endormit.


Lorsqu’elle se réveilla, elle eut peur. Elle voulait être à la maison avec sa mère et se reposer sur sa natte.
A ce moment-là, un petit oiseau bleu se posa sur l’arbre. Il gazouillait : « Salut, n’aie pas peur, je peux t’aider à rentrer chez toi. Suis-moi. »
Abike était surprise d’entendre un oiseau parler.


Abike suivit l’oiseau facilement jusqu’à ce qu’ils arrivent à une bifurcation de la route. La route se séparait en deux directions différentes, l’une allait à gauche et l’autre à droite. Quel chemin devait-elle prendre ?

Abike leva les yeux. Est-ce possible ? L’oiseau avait un morceau de sa natte dans son bec ! Il vola sur le chemin du côté droite et laissa tomber le morceau de la natte. Puis l’oiseau s’envola.



Abike suivit le chemin descendant la colline. Elle entendit les rires et chants des gens de son village.
Abike était heureuse d’être chez elle saine et sauve.



La mère d’Abike étala sa natte et elle lui donna un bol à manger.

Abike commença à compter les carrés, juste pour être sûre qu’ils étaient encore tous là. En comptant, elle était sûre de voir un morceau qui avait été enlevé, puis remis à sa place.
Elle ne rêvait donc pas ! Le petit oiseau bleu était bien réel !

Protecting Your Baby: Vaccinations.text:
Protecting Your Baby: Vaccinations



Protecting Your Baby: Vaccinations





PROTECTING LIFE
Your new baby has arrived! You look at him with joy and love, he is so beautiful. You ask:
— How can we make sure that our baby grows up strong and healthy? Many dangers and diseases could harm him!
— Is there a way to protect our baby? Every mother and father wants to protect their child.
HOW?
Many parents attach cords and amulets to their baby. They have been told to attach them when the baby is born to protect the baby from harmful diseases and other dangers.
But do these traditions give enough protection?
Do the babies who wear these cords and amulets not get sick any more?
PROTECTIVE MEASURES
There are many things you can do to protect the health of your child:
— go to the doctor for regular check-ups during your pregnancy.
— breast feed your baby.

— weigh your baby each month at the health clinic.
— avoid malaria by using a mosquito net over your baby’s bed and give your baby nivaquine in doses the doctor recommends.
— bathe your baby often to keep him clean.
— supplement breast milk with a balanced diet starting at 6 months of age. Talk to your doctor about what foods to feed your baby.
AND... VACCINATE THE CHILD AGAINST DISEASES!
CAN WE AVOID THIS?
Some diseases are very dangerous for a baby.
These diseases may kill the baby or cripple the baby for life. Medicines are not always effective against these diseases. We must do all we can to prevent our children from getting these diseases! The traditional methods of protection are not enough. Let's find a way that will really help us prevent these diseases.
WHY VACCINATE?
Vaccines help the body defend itself against diseases. If the microbe which causes one of these dangerous diseases enters the body, it will be destroyed immediately. A child who has been vaccinated against a disease will not so easily become sick from that disease.
It is important to vaccinate our children BEFORE they become ill.
VACCINATION IS LIKE A FENCE
The goats cannot eat the young plants because they cannot get through the fence.
We can protect children in the same way. Vaccinations build a barrier against dangerous diseases INSIDE the body of the child.
VACCINATION: IT TEACHES THE BODY HOW TO DEFEND ITSELF
The father teaches his child how to kill a snake. He teaches his child how to defend himself against dangerous snakes.
In the same way, vaccinations teach the body of a child how to defend itself against dangerous diseases.
THERE ARE MANY STEPS
We cannot build a fence in a single day, nor can we build a fence using only fence posts.
To build a good fence, we need several days and a variety of materials.
We also have to maintain the fence.
VACCINATIONS
In the same way, we cannot protect a child against diseases with just one injection. The body cannot learn to defend itself against diseases with just one injection.

We have to give the baby a complete series of vaccinations as the baby grows. Then the baby's body can keep out dangerous diseases just like the well-built fence keeps goats out of the garden.
WHAT HAPPENS IF YOU DO NOT VACCINATE YOUR CHILD?
A child who is not vaccinated may get one of the dangerous diseases that can cripple the child for life, or even kill the child.
Parents who refuse to vaccinate their children leave their children at risk.
VACCINATIONS ARE GOOD
If you vaccinate your child, you have protected him from many diseases.
Some babies run a slight fever after their vaccination. This is normal. The baby's body reacts to the vaccination as it learns how to protect the baby from diseases. Give your baby one fourth of an aspirin with water to lower the fever. If the fever continues, take your baby to the health clinic.
The slight illness after the vaccine is not serious. It will quickly go away.
WHAT IF YOUR CHILD IS SICK ON THE DAY YOU ARE TO TAKE HIM IN FOR A VACCINATION?
If your child is sick on the day you planned to take him to the clinic for a vaccination, go ahead and take him to the clinic.
Vaccinations are not dangerous. Even a sick child can be vaccinated. The clinic will tell you whether they can vaccinate your child that day.
PROTECTION = VACCINATION
You can protect your children from the following six diseases by vaccination:
 - tuberculosis
 - tetanus
 - polio
 - whopping cough
 - diphtheria
 - measles
Take your children to the health clinic for vaccinations when they are born. The clinic will tell you when to bring your children in for more vaccinations. It is important to follow this schedule so that your children will be well protected against diseases.

Texte et illustrations :  adaptés de « Protégeons nos enfants par la VACCINATION » avec l’autorisation de l’Atelier du Matériel d’Animation (A.M.A.)

PROTÉGER LA VIE
Votre bébé est là. Vous le regardez avec joie et amour. Il est si beau! Vous vous demandez sûrement:
—  Comment faire pour qu’il grandisse dans de bonnes conditions ? Beaucoup de dangers et de maladies peuvent l’attaquer.
—  Est-ce que nous pouvons l’éviter ? Chaque mère et chaque père veulent protéger leur enfant.
COMMENT?
Beaucoup de parents attachent des cordes et des amulettes à leur enfant. Leurs aînés ont dit de les attacher dès la naissance pour éviter les dangers ou les maladies.
Mais est-ce que ces traditions enlèvent tous les  dangers ?  Est-ce que les enfants qui portent ces cordes et amulettes ne tombent plus malades ?
PROTECTION PAR UN ENSEMBLE DE MESURES
Pour protéger la santé de l’enfant, nous pouvons faire beaucoup de choses :
— Se faire suivre durant la grossesse et l’accouchement
— Donner à l’enfant le lait maternel
— Faire peser l’enfant chaque mois à la PMI
— Eviter le paludisme par la moustiquaire
— Garder l’enfant très propre
— Ajouter de bons repas après 6 mois
ET....FAIRE VACCINER L’ENFANT.
PEUT-ON ÉVITER CELA ?
Il existe des maladies qui sont très dangereuses pour l’enfant. Ces maladies peuvent le rendre infirme pour la vie ou causer sa mort. Les médicaments n’aident pas toujours. Nous devons à tout prix éviter que ces maladies attaquent nos enfants. Nos moyens traditionnels ne sont pas assez puissants.
Cherchons un moyen qui peut vraiment nous aider à PRÉVENIR ces maladies.
POURQUOI VACCINER ?
La vaccination prévient les maladies dangereuses. Le vaccin apprend au corps de l’enfant à se défendre contre ces maladies. Si le microbe de l’une de ces maladies entre dans son corps, il sera tué tout de suite. L’enfant n’attrape plus facilement cette maladie.
Nous devons alors vacciner nos enfants AVANT qu’ils aient la maladie.
LA VACCINATION EST COMME UNE CLÔTURE
Les chèvres ne peuvent pas manger les jeunes plantes, la clôture leur barre la route.
Nous pouvons protéger les enfants de la même façon. La vaccination construit une barrière contre les maladies dangereuses DANS le corps de l’enfant.
LA VACCINATION : C’EST APPRENDRE À SE DÉFENDRE
Le papa apprend à son enfant comment il peut tuer le serpent. Il apprend à l’enfant comment se défendre contre les dangers.
De la même façon, les vaccins apprennent au corps de l’enfant comment il peut se défendre contre ces maladies.
Vacciner l’enfant : c’est donc une manière de rendre l’enfant capable de se défendre.
EN PLUSIEURS ÉTAPES
Nous ne pouvons pas construire une clôture en un seul jour, ni avec des piquets seulement.
Pour construire une bonne clôture, nous avons besoin de plusieurs jours et de plusieurs matériaux.
Nous devons aussi l’entretenir.
EN PLUSIEURS SÉANCES DE VACCINATION
De la même façon, nous ne pouvons pas protéger l’enfant contre les maladies avec une seule piqûre. Le corps de l’enfant ne peut pas apprendre à se défendre en une fois.
Nous devons amener l’enfant aux séances de vaccination plusieurs fois. Il a besoin de plusieurs vaccins à des âges différents. L’infirmier va vous dire quand votre enfant doit être vacciné.
La barrière contre les maladies dangereuses sera forte si l’enfant reçoit tous ses vaccins.
REFUSER ? VOILÀ CE QUI PEUT ARRIVER :
L’enfant qui ne reçoit pas tous ses vaccins peut toujours attraper une des maladies dangereuses. Il risquera toujours d’en mourir ou de devenir handicapé.
Les parents qui refusent les vaccinations laissent leur enfant en danger.
CE QUI EST BON : ACCEPTER LA VACCINATION
L’enfant qui reçoit tous ses vaccins est bien protégé. Il grandira en santé.
Avoir un peu de fièvre après la vaccination, c’est normal. Le corps de l’enfant doit réagir au vaccin. Il commence à apprendre. Un quart d’une aspirine fait vite partir la fièvre.
Si la fièvre continue, allez au Centre de Santé.
Cette petite maladie après la vaccination, n’est pas du tout grave. Elle guérit vite sans laisser des traces.
IL EST MALADE LE JOUR DE LA VACCINATION ? PRÉSENTEZ-LE.
Si votre enfant est malade le jour de la vaccination, allez au Centre de Vaccination.
Les vaccins ne sont plus dangereux.
Même les enfants malades peuvent être vaccinés.
L’infirmière vous dira si votre enfant peut recevoir ses vaccins ce jour-là.
PROTECTION = VACCINATION
Nos enfants peuvent être protégés par la vaccination contre ces six maladies:
 - la tuberculose
 - le tétanos
 - la polio
 - la coqueluche
 - la diphtérie
 - la rougeole            
Faites vacciner votre enfant au dispensaire le plus tôt possible après sa naissance. On vous y dira quand vous devrez ramener votre enfant pour d’autres vaccinations. Il est important de suivre le programme de vaccinations afin de bien protéger vos enfants contre les maladies.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Transmission du coronavirus

Gobani was a very tall man. The villagers called Gobani the Gentle Giant, because he was quiet and friendly. He was not like the bad giants you read about in some stories.

During the day Gobani worked in his garden. His hoe was very short and he had to bend right down to work with it. His back must have hurt from all the bending down.
Thimba lived next door to Gobani. It made him sad to see Gobani struggling with his short hoe, or bending down to get through his door.

Thimba decided to help Gobani. He spoke to the village elders and asked them for help. But before they could help, they needed to know exactly how tall Gobani was.
Thimba asked Gobani, "How tall are you?" Gobani estimated, "I am about 2,5m tall."
He lay down on the bed and explained, "I know my mattress is 1,5m long. You can see that my legs hang over the end for at least another metre. So that means I must be at least 2,5m tall."
Thimba could now tell the elders that Gobani was 2,5m tall. That is very tall!
Thimba could now start working on his secret plan.
Thimba, Gobani and his pet chicken, Choke, set off for market on Gobani's tiny bike. Gobani had to lift his feet above the handle bars in between peddling. Thimba hid inside the basket, too frightened to watch the road as the bike swerved from side to side.
At the village square, Gobani got off his bicycle, and a swarm of friendly villagers surrounded him. The village chief welcomed him.
"Hello Gentle Giant," he said. "Young Thimba told us that you face problems in your life, being so tall. We want to help you. We will make sure that everything you need is the right size for you. Soon your problems will disappear. Just wait and see."
The villagers worked around the clock to make sure everything Gobani needed was made the correct size.

Look at his new hoe. Compare the length of the new hoe with his old one. The new one looks twice as long. How long do you think it is? More than one metre? Less than two metres?
Next the villagers helped Gobani build a taller door frame with a new door for his house. It was a bit taller than Gobani, so he no longer had to stoop down to get inside. Just right!

Look closely at the picture. Gobani is about 2,5 metres tall. How tall do you think his new door frame is?
Next came a brand new bed and mattress with extra-long sheets and blankets to cover Gobani's long body from head to toe. At last he could look forward to hours of peaceful rest and sleep. His feet would no longer hang over the end of the mattress.

Look how his whole body is now completely covered. There is even some space left over at the end.
The chief asked one of the village steel workers to make a giant-sized bicycle for Gobani. It had a basket that was big enough for both Thimba and Choke to sit in. The saddle, the handle bars and the peddles were just the right height. Gobani did not have to drag his legs on the road or swing them over the handle bars to keep them out of the way.
The carpenters made Gobani a new table to sit at with legs that are at least 1,5m tall. Now when he sits down to eat, his feet touch the ground.
Thimba sits next to him on a very tall stool. He needs a ladder to reach the top.

Count how many rungs he has to climb to be level with Gobani. How tall do you think the ladder is?
Gobani's new hoe made it easy for him to plant and harvest. His garden became a forest! Gobani leaves baskets of fruit outside his front door for the villagers, to show how thankful he is for their help.

And this all began with young Thimba's dream to make life easier for his friend, the Gentle Giant.

L'aide de Thimba !





Gobani était un homme très grand. Les villageois appelaient Gobani le géant gentil parce qu’il était calme et gentil. Il n’était pas comme les mauvais géants dont tu peux parfois lire des histoires.
Pendant la journée, Gobani travaillait dans son jardin. Sa houe était très petite et il devait beaucoup se courber pour travailler quand il s’en servait. Son dos devait lui faire mal, car il devait tout le temps le courber.

Thimba vivait à côté de Gobani. Il était triste de voir Gobani se battre avec sa petite houe, ou se courber pour pouvoir passer par sa porte.
Thimba décida d’aider Gobani. Il parla aux anciens du village et leur demanda de l’aide. Mais avant de pouvoir aider Gobani, ils devaient savoir exactement quelle était sa taille.

Thimba demanda à Gobani, « Quelle est ta taille ? » Gobani estima, « Je mesure environ 2,5 mètres. » Il se posa sur son lit et lui expliqua, « Je sais que mon matelas mesure 1,5 m de longueur. Tu peux voir que mes jambes dépassent du lit d’au moins encore un mètre. Donc cela veut dire que je dois mesurer au moins 2,5 m. » ﻿Thimba pouvait maintenant informer les anciens que Gobani mesurait 2,5 m. C’est très grand !

Thimba pouvait maintenant travailler sur son plan secret. Thimba, Gobani et son animal de compagnie, une poule domestique, Choke, partirent pour aller au marché avec le minuscule vélo de Gobani. Quand il pédalait, Gobani devait poser ses jambes sur le guidon de temps en temps. Thimba s’était caché dans le panier, car il avait trop peur de regarder le chemin quand le vélo déviait d’un côté et ensuite de l’autre.

À la place du village, Gobani descendit de son vélo et une foule amicale de villageois l’entoura. Le chef du village lui souhaita la bienvenue.

« Bonjour géant gentil », lui dit-il. « Le jeune Thimba nous a dit que tu es confronté à des problèmes dans ta vie à cause de ta taille. Nous voulons t’aider. Bientôt, tes problèmes disparaîtront. Tu vas voir. »

Les villageois ont travaillé sans relâche pour être sûrs que tout ce dont Gobani avait besoin ait la bonne taille.


Regarde sa nouvelle houe. Compare la longueur de la nouvelle houe avec celle de l’ancienne. La nouvelle a l’air d’être deux fois plus longue. D’après toi, quelle est sa longueur ? Plus d’un mètre ? Moins de deux mètres ? 
Ensuite, les villageois ont aidé Gobani à construire pour sa maison une nouvelle porte avec son cadre afin qu’elle soit plus haute. Elle était un peu plus haute que Gobani, donc il n’avait plus besoin de se voûter pour y entrer. C’était parfait !


Regarde l’image de près. Gobani mesure environ 2,5 mètres. D’après toi, quelle est la hauteur du cadre de sa nouvelle porte ?
Il y avait aussi un lit et un matelas flambant neufs avec des draps et des couvertures très longs pour couvrir le corps de Gobani de la tête aux pieds. Il pouvait enfin se réjouir de pouvoir dormir et se reposer tranquillement pendant des heures. Ses pieds n’allaient plus dépasser du matelas.
Regarde comment son corps entier est maintenant entièrement couvert. Il reste même encore de l’espace au bout.

Le chef demanda aux gens du village qui savaient travailler les métaux de faire un vélo géant pour Gobani. Il avait un panier assez grand pour que Thimba et Choke puissent s’y asseoir ensemble. La selle, le guidon et les pédales étaient à la bonne hauteur. Gobani n’avait plus besoin de laisser traîner ses jambes sur la route ou de les laisser pendre sur le guidon de sorte qu’elles ne le dérangent pas.
Les menuisiers firent une nouvelle table pour Gobani, avec des pieds d’une longueur d’au moins 1,5 m. Maintenant, quand il s’assoit, ses pieds touchent le sol. Thimba est assis à côté de lui sur un tabouret très haut. Il lui faut une échelle pour y monter dessus.

Compte combien d’échelons il doit monter pour être de la même hauteur que Gobani. Quelle est selon toi la longueur de l’échelle ?
Lorsqu’il doit planter et récolter, le travail est pour Gobani plus facile grâce à sa nouvelle houe. Son jardin est devenu une forêt ! Gobani dépose des paniers de fruits devant sa porte d’entrée pour les villageois, car il veut leur montrer combien il est reconnaissant de leur aide.
Et tout ceci a commencé avec le rêve du jeune Thimba de rendre la vie plus facile à son ami, le géant gentil.

In the village of Bethany, about two miles from Jerusalem, lived a man named Lazarus with his sisters Mary and Martha. They were good friends of Jesus.
One day the two sisters sent someone with an important message for Jesus, saying, “Lord, the one you love is sick.”
But Jesus said, “Lazarus’s sickness will not end in death. No, it happened for God’s glory so that the Son of God will receive glory from this.”
So Jesus waited two more days. Then he said to the disciples, “Let us go back to Judea.”
The disciples said, “Not long ago the Jews there tried to stone you. Why do you want to go back there now?”
So Jesus told them plainly, “Lazarus is dead. And for your sake I am glad I was not there, because now you will really believe. Let us go see him.”
Thomas said to the other disciples, “Well, let us go, too, and die with Jesus.”
When Martha heard someone say Jesus was coming, she went out to meet him. "Lord,” Martha said to Jesus, “if you had been here, my brother would not have died. Yet, even now I know that whatever you ask from God, God will give you."
Jesus said to her, "I am the one who raises people from the dead; I am the one who gives them life. Whoever trusts in me, even if he dies, he will live again. Do you believe me?”
"Yes, Lord!” Martha said to Jesus, “I trust what you say and I trust who you are, that you are the Messiah, the Son of God.”
Martha went and got her sister Mary. Mary fell down at Jesus’ feet and cried, “Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.”
Jesus was very troubled by their grief. He wept.
Then he went with them to the cave where they had put Lazarus’s body. There was a large stone rolled across the entrance. Jesus commanded, “Take away the stone.”
Martha said, “But Lord, Lazarus has been dead four days. By now there will be a terrible smell.”
Jesus said to her, “I told you that if you believed in me, you would see the glory of God.” So they took away the stone.
Jesus looked up toward heaven and said, “Father, I thank you that you have heard me. I know that you always hear me. I said this for the sake of the people who are standing here so that they might put their trust in you and have confidence in the fact that you sent me.”
Then Jesus shouted, “Lazarus, come out!”
And Lazarus, the man who had died, came out of the tomb. The strips of cloth were still wrapped around his hands and feet. And a cloth was still wrapped around his face.
Jesus ordered, “Unwrap the grave cloths, and let him go!” Then many of the people who saw what Jesus had done believed in him.
But some of the others went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done. So the chief priests and the Pharisees began to look for any way to arrest Jesus and put him to death.

134 Jésus ramène Lazare à la vie





Des amis de Jésus habitent dans la ville de Béthanie, à environ trois kilomètres de Jérusalem. C’était deux sœurs nommées Marie et Marthe et leur frère Lazare.
Un jour, les deux sœurs envoient dire à Jésus : « Seigneur, ton ami est malade. »
Quand Jésus entend cela, il dit: « La maladie de Lazare ne va pas le faire mourir, mais elle va server à montrer la gloire de Dieu. Ainsi elle donnera de la gloire au Fils de Dieu. »
Pendant deux jours, Jésus reste là où il est. Ensuite il dit à ses disciples: « Retournons en Judée. »
Ses disciples lui disent: « Maître, l’autre jour, les Juifs en Judée cherchaient à te tuer, et pour le faire, ils voulaient te jeter des pierres. Et tu veux retourner là-bas ? »
Jésus leur répond: « Notre ami Lazare est mort. Je n’étais pas là-bas et je m’en réjouis, à cause de vous. De cette façon, vous pourrez croire en moi. Mais allons auprès de Lazare. »
Alors Thomas dit aux autre disciples : « Allons-y nous aussi, pour mourir avec Jésus ! »
Jésus arrive près de Béthanie. Marthe apprend que Jésus arrive et elle part à sa rencontre. Elle lui dit : « Seigneur, si tu avais été là, mon frère ne serait pas mort. Mais, même maintenant, Dieu te donnera tout ce que tu lui demanderas, j’en suis sûre. »
Jésus lui dit: « Celui qui relève de la mort, c’est moi. La vie, c’est moi. Celui qui croit en moi aura la vie, même s’il meurt. Est-ce que tu crois cela ? »
Marthe répond à Jésus: « Oui, Seigneur, je crois que tu es le Messie, le Fils de Dieu.”
Après que Marthe a dit cela, elle part appeler sa sœur Marie. Marie se lève tout de suite et elle va trouver Jésus. Elle se jette à ses pieds et lui dit : « Seigneur, si tu avais été là, mon frère ne serait pas mort. »
Jésus voit qu’elle pleure. Alors Jésus est bouleversé et troublé, et il se met à pleurer.
Jésus va vers la tombe de Lazare. C’est une grotte avec une grosse pierre placée devant l’entrée. Jésus dit : « Enlevez la pierre ! »
Marthe lui dit: « Seigneur, il doit déjà sentir mauvais. Il est dans la tombe depuis quatre jours. »
Mais Jésus répond: « Je t’ai dit: "Si tu crois, tu verras la gloire de Dieu." » Alors ils enlèvent la pierre.
Jésus lève les yeux vers le ciel et il dit: « Père, je te dis merci, parce que tu m’as écouté. Tu m’écoutes toujours, je le sais. Mais je dis cela à cause des gens qui sont autour de moi. Ainsi ils pourront croire que c’est toi qui m’as envoyé. »
Ensuite Jésus crie d’une voix forte : « Lazare, sors de là ! »
Et Lazare sort, lui qui était mort. Il a les pieds et les mains attachés avec des bandes de tissu. Son visage est enveloppé dans un linge.
Jésus dit aux gens: « Enlevez-lui tout cela et laissez-le partir. »
Beaucoup de gens ont vu ce que Jésus a fait et se mettent à croire en lui. Mais certains d’entre eux vont trouver les Pharisiens et ils leur racontent ce que Jésus a fait. Alors les chefs des prêtres et les Pharisiens décident de faire mourir Jésus.

Cuu nǝ̃ǝ̃m'n tammã.original_text:
La Création

Cette histoire biblique est tirée de: Genèse 1-2
C’est ainsi que le début de toute chose arriva. Dieu créa l’univers et tout ce qui s’y trouve en six jours. Au début, il y avait des ténèbres, et la terre était vide et sans forme. l’Esprit de Dieu se mouvait au-dessus de l’eau.
Puis Dieu dit: “Que la lumière soit!” et la lumière fut. Dieu vit que la lumière était bonne et il l’appela “jour”. Il la sépara des ténèbres, qu’Il appela “nuit”. Dieu créa la lumière le premier jour de la création.
Le second jour de la création, Dieu créa le ciel au-dessus de la terre par sa parole. Il créa le ciel en séparant les eaux d’en haut des eaux d’en bas.
Le troisième jour, par sa parole, Dieu sépara l’étendue des eaux avec l’étendue sèche . Il appela l’étendue sèche “terre” et l’étendue des eaux “mers”. Dieu vit que ce qu’il avait créé était bon.
Puis Dieu dit: “Que la terre produise toutes sortes d’arbres et d’herbes”. Et c’est ce qui arriva. Dieu vit que ce qu’Il avait créé était bon.

Le quatrième jour de la création, Dieu par sa parole crea le soleil, la lune et les étoiles. Dieu les créa pour faire briller la lumière sur la terre et pour indiquer le jour et la nuit, les saisons et les années. Et Dieu vit que ce qu’il avait créé était bon.
Le cinquième jour, Dieu par sa parole créa tout ce qui nage dans l’eau ainsi que tous les oiseaux. Dieu vit que c’était bon et Il les bénit.
Le sixième jour de la création, Dieu dit: “Qu’il y ait toutes sortes d’animaux terrestres!” Et cela se passa exactement comme Dieu l’avait dit. C’étaient les animaux domestiques, les animaux sauvages et rampants. Et Dieu vit que cela était bon.
Puis Dieu dit: “Faisons l’homme à notre image selon notre ressemblance. Il aura le pouvoir sur la terre et sur tous les animaux.”
Alors Dieu prit un peu de terre, forma l’homme, et lui communica la vie. Le nom de cet homme était Adam. Dieu planta un jardin dans lequel Il plaça Adam pour qu’il y vive, et en prenne soin.
Au milieu du jardin, Dieu planta deux arbres spéciaux, l’arbre de la vie et l’arbre de la connaissance du bien et du mal. Dieu dit à Adam qu’il pouvait manger les fruits de n’importe quel arbre du jardin, sauf celui de la connaissance du bien et du mal. Car s’il en mangeait, il mourrait.
Puis Dieu dit : “il n’est pas bon que l’homme soit seul.”
Alors Dieu fit tomber Adam dans un profond sommeil. Puis Il prit l’une de ses côtes, en forma une femme et l’amena vers lui.
Quand Adam la vit, il dit: “Enfin! Celle-ci est comme moi. On l’appellera”femme“, parce qu’elle a été prise de moi. C’est pour cela que l’homme quittera son père et sa mère et s’attachera à sa femme, et ils deviendront une seule chair.”
Dieu fit l’homme et la femme à son image. Il les bénit et leur dit: “Ayez beaucoup d’enfants et de petit-fils pour remplir la terre!” Et Dieu vit que tout ce qu’Il avait fait était très bon et Il en fut ravi. Tout cela arriva le sixième jour de la création.
Quand le septième jour arriva, Dieu avait déjà achevé son œuvre. Alors Il se reposa de tout ce qu’Il avait fait. Il bénit le septième jour et le sanctifia parce que ce jour là il se reposa. C’est ainsi que Dieu créa l’univers et tout ce qui s’y trouve.
La Création
