26. Jesus Starts His Ministry


After overcoming Satan’s temptations, Jesus returned in the power of the Holy Spirit to the region of Galilee where he lived. Jesus went from place to place teaching. Everyone spoke well of him.
Jesus went to the town of Nazareth where he had lived during his childhood. On the Sabbath, he went to the place of worship. They handed him the scroll of the prophet Isaiah so that he would read from it. Jesus opened up the scroll and read part of it to the people.
Jesus read, “God has given me his Spirit so that I can proclaim good news to the poor, freedom to captives, recovery of sight for the blind, and release to the oppressed. This is the year of the Lord’s favor.”
Then Jesus sat down. Everybody watched him closely. They knew the passage of scripture that he had just read referred to the Messiah. Jesus said, “The words I just read to you are happening right now.” All the people were amazed. “Isn’t this the son of Joseph?” they said.
Then Jesus said, “It is true that no prophet is accepted in his own hometown. During the time of the prophet Elijah, there were many widows in Israel. But when it did not rain for three and a half years, God did not send Elijah to help a widow from Israel, but rather to a widow from a different nation.”
Jesus continued saying, “And during the time of the prophet Elisha, there were many people in Israel with skin diseases. But Elisha did not heal any of them. He only healed the skin disease of Naaman, a commander of Israel’s enemies.” The people who were listening to Jesus were Jews. So when they heard him say this, they were furious at him.
The people of Nazareth dragged Jesus out of the place of worship and brought him to the edge of a cliff to throw him off of it in order to kill him. But Jesus walked through the crowd and left the town of Nazareth.
Then Jesus went throughout the region of Galilee, and large crowds came to him. They brought many people who were sick or handicapped, including those who could not see, walk, hear, or speak, and Jesus healed them.
Many people who had demons in them were brought to Jesus. At Jesus’ command, the demons came out of the people, and often shouted, “You are the Son of God!” The crowds of people were amazed and worshiped God.
Then Jesus chose twelve men whom he called his apostles. The apostles traveled with Jesus and learned from him.
26. Jesus Starts His Ministry
26.Wa Yesu kǝ kaft thlǝnǝkǝ\nLabaɗa nga.original_text:
26. Jésus Commence son Ministère


Après avoir surmonté les tentations de Satan, Jésus, revêtu de la puissance du Saint-Esprit, retourna en Galilée où il habitait. Jésus alla enseigner de ville en ville. Sa renommée se répandit dans tout le pays.
Jésus alla à Nazareth où il avait vécu pendant son enfance. Il entra dans la Synagogue le jour du Sabbat. On lui remit le manuscrit du prophète Esaïe pour qu’il puisse le lire. L’ayant déroulé, il en lut un passage.
Jésus lut: “Dieu m’a donné son Esprit pour que j’annonce la Bonne Nouvelle aux pauvres, que je libère les opprimés et les captifs, et que je rende la vue aux aveugles. C’est l’année de grâce du Seigneur.”
Puis Jésus s’assit. Tout le monde avait le regard fixé sur lui. Ils savaient tous que la partie des Saintes Ecritures qu’il venait de lire parlait du Messie. Jésus dit: “Cette parole de l’Écriture que je viens de vous lire, est accomplie.” Tout le monde était étonné. “N’est-ce pas le fils de Joseph?” Dirent-ils.
Puis Jésus dit: “Je vous le dis en vérité, aucun prophète n’est bien reçu dans son pays”. Du temps du prophète Elie, il y avait plusieurs veuves en Israël. Mais quand il ne plut pas pendant trois ans et demi, Dieu n’envoya pas Elie aider une veuve d’Israël, mais plutôt une veuve d’une autre nation."
Jésus continua en disant que du temps du prophète Elisée, Il y avait beaucoup de gens en Israël qui avaient des maladies de la peau. Mais Elisée n’en guérit aucun. Il ne guérit que la lèpre de Naaman, un général des ennemis d’Israël. Les gens qui écoutaient Jésus étaient Juifs, alors quand ils l’entendirent dire cela, ils furent furieux contre lui.
Le peuple de Nazareth chassa Jésus de la Synagogue et le mena au sommet d’une montagne afin de l’en précipiter pour le tuer. Mais Jésus, se faufila dans la foule, et quitta la ville de Nazareth.
Puis Jésus s’en alla dans la région de Galilée et de grandes foules le suivirent. Elles lui amenèrent les malades ou infirmes, y compris ceux qui ne pouvaient pas voir, marcher, entendre ou parler, et Jésus les guérit tous.
Beaucoup de gens possédés par des démons furent amenés devant Jésus. A son commandement, les démons sortaient des gens, souvent en criant, “Tu es le Fils de Dieu!” Les foules étaient saisies d’étonnement et louaient Dieu.
Puis Jésus choisit douze hommes qu’il appela ses disciples. Ils voyagèrent avec lui et apprirent beaucoup de choses de lui.

When the Israelites had been slaves in Egypt for about 400 years, God heard the cries of his suffering people and remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
In the land of Midian, Moses tended the sheep of his father-in-law Jethro.
One day, Moses led the sheep across the desert to Sinai, the mountain of God.
There Moses saw a bush with flames coming from it. But the bush was not destroyed by the fire.
Moses was curious and went closer to look at the burning bush to see why the fire did not destroy it.
As Moses came closer, God called to him from within the burning bush saying, “Moses! Moses!”
And Moses answered, “Here I am.”
Moses covered his face because he was afraid to look at God. Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
“I have seen the sufferings of my people in Egypt. So I have come to rescue them and bring them out of Egypt to the good land of Canaan. I am sending you back to Pharaoh to lead my people out of Egypt.”
But Moses replied to God, “I have no status! I cannot go to Pharaoh or lead the people of Israel out of Egypt!”
And God said, “I will be with you. And when you bring my people out of Egypt, all of you will worship me here on this mountain. That will prove I am the one who sent you.”
Then Moses said, “If I tell the Israelites, 'The God your ancestors worshiped has sent me to you,' they will say, 'What is his name?' Then what shall I say to them?”
God replied, “I AM Who I AM. Tell them that the One who is called I AM has sent you to them. This name will be my name forever…. This is what all future generations are to call me.”
“Tell the leaders of Israel that I, the Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob appeared to you, and promised to rescue my people from their suffering in Egypt.”
“Then go with the leaders of Israel to the Pharaoh, and say, ‘Let us Israelites go out into the desert to worship the Lord our God.’”
Moses asked the Lord, “What do I tell the leaders if they do not believe me? What if they say, ‘The Lord did not appear to you!’?”
The Lord said, “Look at that walking stick you are holding. Throw it on the ground.”
So Moses threw his walking stick down on the ground.
The stick became a snake and Moses ran away from it! Then the Lord said, “Pick up the snake by its tail.”
Moses obeyed and picked up the snake by its tail. Immediately the snake became Moses’ walking stick in his hand.
Then the Lord said, “Perform this sign. Then the leaders of Israel will believe that the Lord, the God of their ancestors, has appeared to you.”
God spoke to Moses again, saying, “Put your hand inside your coat.”
So Moses did that.
When he took his hand out, it was white with leprosy!
Then God said, “Put your hand back inside your coat.”
So Moses put his hand inside his coat. When he took it out, his hand was healthy again!
Then the Lord said, “If they don’t believe these two miraculous signs, take some water from the Nile River and pour it out on dry ground, and it will become blood.”
Then Moses said to the Lord, “Oh Lord, I am not a good speaker.”
The Lord said, “I am the one who makes people able or unable to speak or hear or see. Now go. I will teach you what to say, and I will help you speak.”
But Moses said, “Oh Lord, please send someone else to do this.”
Then the Lord was angry and said, “Your brother Aaron can speak well. You tell him what to say and he will speak to the people. Take the walking stick with you. You will perform miraculous signs with it.”
Moses went back to Jethro and said, “Please let me go back to Egypt and see if my relatives are still alive.” And Jethro said, “Go and may God give you peace.”
So Moses took his family and the walking stick and returned to Egypt.

Les années ont passé, et le roi d'Égypte est mort. Alors Dieu a commencé à délivrer son peuple, les enfants d'Israël, de leur esclavage en Égypte.
Dans le pays de Madian, Moïse prenait soin des troupeaux de moutons de Jéthro, son beau-père,
Un jour, Moïse a conduit les troupeaux à travers le désert jusqu’à Horeb, la montagne de Dieu.
Là Moïse a vu un buisson qui brûlait. Mais le buisson n’était pas consumé par le feu.
Moïse était curieux et il est allé voir d’un peu plus près ce buisson embrasé pour voir pourquoi il n'a pas été consumé par le feu.
Comme Moïse se rapprochait, Dieu l'appela du milieu du buisson brûlant disant: «Moïse! Moïse!"
Moïse a répondu: "Me voici."
Moïse s’est couvert le visage parce qu'il avait peur de regarder Dieu. Alors l'Éternel a parlé à Moïse, et a dit
«J’ai vu les souffrances de mon peuple en Égypte. Je suis venu pour les sauver et pour les faire sortir d'Égypte et les amener au bon pays de Canaan. Je te renvoie à Pharaon. Alors, tu vas conduire mon peuple hors d'Égypte ».
Moïse dit à Dieu: «Mais je ne suis personne de spécial. Comment puis-je amener les Israélites hors d'Égypte?"
Et Dieu dit: «Je serai avec toi. Après que tu mènes le peuple hors d'Égypte, tu m’adoreras ici, sur cette montagne. Ce sera la preuve que je t’ai envoyé ".
Ensuite Moïse a dit: "Si je dis aux enfants d'Israël: Le Dieu de vos pères m'a envoyé vers vous», ils diront: «Quel est son nom? Alors que dois-je leur dire? "
Dieu a dit: «Je suis qui je suis. Dis leur, celui qui s’appelle JE SUIS m'a envoyé vers vous. Voilà mon nom pour toujours. C’est ce que toutes les générations futures devront m’appeler.»
Dieu a dit aussi: «Dis aux anciens d'Israël que moi, le Seigneur, j’ai promis de les faire sortir de leur misère en Égypte."
«Puis, avec les anciens, va devant Pharaon et dis-lui:« Laisse-nous, Israélites, partir dans le désert pour adorer le Seigneur notre Dieu. "
Moïse n’était pas sûr qu'il puisse faire ce que Dieu voulait qu'il fasse. Alors, il a demandé à Dieu, «Que ferai-je s'ils ne me croient pas et disent:« Le Seigneur ne t’est a pas apparu. "
Dieu a vu que Moïse avait peur. Alors Il dit à Moïse de jeter son bâton sur le sol.
Moïse a jeté son bâton sur le sol.
Et quand il l'a fait ça le bâton est devenu un serpent et Moïse a pris la fuite devant lui! Alors le Seigneur lui a dit: «Prends-le par la queue.»
Moïse a obéi à Dieu et a pris le serpent par la queue. Et quand il l'a fait le serpent s’est immédiatement retransformé dans le bâton de Moïse.
Et Dieu a dit à Moïse de faire la même chose devant les anciens d'Israël afin qu'ils puisent croire que Dieu lui était apparu.
Alors Dieu a parlé encore à Moïse, disant: «Mets ta main dans ton habit."
Donc Moïse a fait cela.
Mais quand il a retiré sa main, elle était blanche, couverte de lèpre.
Alors Dieu a dit, « Remets ta main dans ton habit. »
Moïse l’a fait et quand il a repris sa main elle était de nouveau en bonne santé!
Alors le Seigneur a dit: «S'ils ne croient pas en ces deux miracles, alors prends un peu d'eau de la rivière du Nil et verse-la sur la terre sèche et elle deviendra du sang. »
Ensuite, Moïse a dit au Seigneur. « Oh Seigneur, je ne sais pas bien parler. »
Le Seigneur a dit: «Je suis celui qui rend les gens capables ou incapables de parler ou d’entendre ou de voir. Maintenant vas-y. Je vais t’enseigner ce qu'il faut dire, et je vais t’aider à parler. »
Mais Moïse a dit: «Oh Seigneur, s'il vous plaît envoyez quelqu'un d'autre pour le faire."
Alors, la colère de Dieu s’est enflammée contre Moïse et il a dit, « Ton frère Aaron est éloquent. Tu lui diras ce qu’il faudra dire et il le dira au peuple. Maintenant prends ton bâton avec toi et tu vas accomplir des signes miraculeux avec lui. »
Moïse est retourné auprès de Jéthro et lui a dit : « Permet-moi de retourner en Egypte pour voir si mes frères hébreux sont encore vivants. » Jéthro lui a répondu : « Va en paix ! »
Alors Moïse a pris sa femme et ses fils et le bâton que Dieu lui a dit de prendre, et il est retourné en Egypte.

(42) Chicken and Millipede

Level 4, Book 42, Version 2.0


Chicken and Millipede were friends, but they were always competing with each other. One day they decided to play football to see who was
the best player.

They went to the football field and started their game. Chicken was fast, but Millipede was faster. Chicken kicked far, but Millipede kicked further. Chicken started to feel grumpy.

They decided to play a penalty shoot-out. First Millipede was goal keeper. Chicken scored only one goal. Then it was the chicken’s turn to defend the goal.



Millipede kicked the ball and scored. Millipede dribbled the ball and scored. Millipede headed the ball and scored. Millipede scored five goals.


Chicken was furious that she lost. She was a very bad loser. Millipede started laughing because his friend was making such a fuss.


Chicken was so angry that she opened her beak wide and swallowed the millipede.


As Chicken was walking home, she met Mother Millipede. Mother Millipede asked, “Have you seen my child?” Chicken didn’t say anything. Mother Millipede was worried.


Then Mother Millipede heard a tiny voice. “Help me, Mum!” cried the voice. Mother Millipede looked around and listened carefully. The voice came from inside the chicken.


Mother Millipede shouted, “Use your special gift my child!” Millipedes can make a bad smell and a terrible taste. Chicken began to feel ill.


Chicken burped. Then she swallowed and spat. Then she sneezed and coughed. And coughed. The millipede was disgusting!


Chicken coughed until she coughed out the millipede in her stomach. Mother Millipede and her child crawled up a tree to hide.


From that time, chickens and millipedes  were enemies.

After the soldiers crucified Jesus, the unbelieving Jewish leaders said to Pilate, “That liar, Jesus, said he would rise from the dead after three days. Someone must guard the tomb to make sure that his disciples do not steal the body and then say he has risen from the dead.”
Pilate said, “Take some soldiers and make the tomb as secure as you can.” So they placed a seal on the stone at the entrance of the tomb and put the soldiers there to make sure no one could steal the body.

Pilate dit: “Prenez des soldats pour garder le tombeau.” Alors ils scellèrent le roc à l’entrée du tombeau et mirent des soldats devant pour que personne ne vole le corps de Jésus.
Le lendemain de la mise au tombeau était le jour du Sabbat donc il n’était pas permis aux Juifs d’aller aux cimétières ce jour-là. Au lendemain du Sabbat, très tôt le matin, des femmes se rendirent au tombeau pour mettre des huiles aromatiques sur le corps de Jésus.
Soudain, il y eut un violent tremblement de terre. Un ange du Seigneur qui avait l’apparence de l’éclair, descendit du ciel, roula la pierre de côté et s’assit sur elle. Les soldats gardant le tombeau furent saisis de peur et tombèrent comme morts, face contre terre.
Quand les femmes arrivèrent, l’ange leur dit: “N’ayez pas peur. Jésus n’est plus ici. Il est ressuscité comme Il l’avait annoncé. Venez voir!” Les femmes regardèrent l’endroit où le corps de Jésus avait été déposé. Le corps n’était plus là!
Alors l’ange dit aux femmes: “Allez vite annoncer à ses disciples que Jésus est ressuscité d’entre les morts et qu’Il vous attend déjà en Galilée.”
Les femmes étaient effrayées mais en même temps remplies d’une grande joie. Elles coururent porter la Bonne Nouvelle aux disciples.
Tandis que les femmes partaient leur annoncer cette Bonne Nouvelle, Jésus leur apparut, et elles l’adorèrent. Jésus dit: “N’ayez aucune crainte. Allez dire à mes disciples de se rendre en Galilée, c’est là qu’ils me verront.”

After Cain and Abel were born, Adam had many other children and descendants.
In those days people lived a long time—about 900 years. But no matter how long people lived, they died.
After many generations, many people were living on the earth. And the people had become very evil and more and more violent.
Everything people thought or imagined was always totally evil. So the Lord was grieved that he had made them.
Because people were so evil the Lord said, “I will completely destroy all the people, and all the animals and birds living on the earth. And I will cause people to live much shorter lives.”
A man named Noah lived during that time. After he was 500 years old, he became the father of three sons: Shem, Ham and Japheth. Noah was not evil like everybody else.
Noah was a righteous man who lived in close fellowship with God. And the Lord was pleased with Noah and did not want to destroy him and his family.
The Lord said to Noah, "I will bring a flood upon the earth which will destroy all living creatures, because people are violent all over the earth. But I will make a covenant with you."
“Build a very big wooden boat. Cover the outside and inside with tar. Build it this size: 140 meters long, 23 meters wide, and 13.5 meters high.”
“Build the boat with three levels inside and many rooms. Cover it with a roof. Put a door on the side.”
So Noah built the boat just the way God had told him.
God commanded Noah, saying, “Bring your wife into the boat.”
“And bring your three sons and their wives into the boat with you.”
“A male and a female of every kind of animal and bird will come to you.”
“Bring them into the boat with you to keep them alive.” God told Noah to take seven pairs of some animals and birds acceptable for sacrifice.
God commanded Noah, “Bring enough food for you, your family and all the animals to eat during the flood.” So Noah did everything that God commanded.
When Noah was 600 years old, he and his wife, their three sons and their wives and all the animals and birds entered the boat, just as God had commanded. And the Lord shut the door behind them.
After seven days, all the underground waters erupted from the earth. Heavy rain fell in mighty torrents from the sky.
It rained constantly for forty days and forty nights.
The flood increased and lifted the boat high above the earth. The boat floated on the surface of the water.
The water covered all the mountains on the earth. All the living things on earth died—all the birds and animals of every kind, and all the people.
Only Noah and those people, animals, and birds that were with him in the boat remained alive.
But God did not forget Noah and all the animals with him in the boat. God caused the underground waters to stop flowing and the rains to stop.
Then, God sent a wind to blow over the earth. Very slowly, the floodwaters receded.
150 days after the flood began, the boat rested on the mountains in a region called Ararat.
Noah and his family stayed in the boat and waited while the waters continued to recede.
Forty days later, Noah opened the window of the boat and released a raven. It did not come back. It just kept flying around until the waters were dried up.
Then Noah released a dove to see if it could find dry ground.
But the dove could not find a dry place to land. So the dove returned to the boat because there was water all over the surface of the earth.
Seven days later Noah released the dove again.
This time it returned to the boat with a freshly plucked olive leaf in its beak. Then Noah knew that the floodwaters were almost gone.
Noah waited seven more days and released the dove again. This time the dove did not return to the boat. By this time, Noah and his family had been in the boat for almost a year.
Two months later, the earth was completely dry. Then God told Noah, “Come out of the boat; you, your wife, your sons and their wives.”
“Release all the animals and birds. Then they can breed and reproduce and spread out over all the earth.” So Noah and his family and all the animals left the boat.
Then Noah built an altar to the Lord. There he sacrificed burnt offerings of animals and birds approved for sacrifice.
This pleased the Lord very much. And the Lord said to himself, “I will never again destroy all living things this way.”
God said, “While the earth remains, there will be seasons for planting and harvesting. There will also be daytime and nighttime.”
God blessed Noah and his family and told them, "Have many children so that your descendants will spread out and live all over the earth."
“Just as I gave you plants to eat, now animals will also be food for you. But do not eat any meat that still has blood in it.”
And God said, “Anyone who murders another person must be killed by others, because God made man in His own image.”
Then God said to Noah and his sons, “I am making a covenant with you and your descendants and with every living creature on earth. I will never again destroy all living things by a flood.”
So God put the rainbow in the sky to be a reminder of His promise.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Understanding how COVID-19 vaccines work
To understand how COVID-19 vaccines work, it helps to first look at how our bodies fight illness. When germs, such as the virus that causes COVID-19, invade our bodies, they attack and multiply. This invasion, called an infection, is what causes illness. Our immune system uses several tools to fight infection. Blood contains red cells, which carry oxygen to tissues and organs, and white or immune cells, which fight infection. Different types of white blood cells fight infection in different ways.
The first time a person is infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, it can take several days or weeks for their body to make and use all the germ-fighting tools needed to get over the infection. After the infection, the person’s immune system remembers what it learned about how to protect the body against that disease.
The immune system can go into action quickly if the body encounters the same virus again. Experts are still learning how long a person is protected against the virus that causes COVID-19.
COVID-19 vaccines help our bodies develop immunity to the virus that causes COVID-19 without us having to get the illness. Different types of vaccines work in different ways to offer protection. But with all types of vaccines, the body will remember how to fight that virus in the future. Some vaccines require more than one shot.
It typically takes a few weeks after vaccination for the body to make and use all the germ-fighting tools needed. Therefore, it is possible that a person could be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 just before or just after vaccination and then get sick because the vaccine did not have enough time to provide protection.
Sometimes after vaccination, the process of building immunity can cause symptoms, such as fever. These symptoms are normal and are signs that the body is building immunity.
The Bottom Line
Getting vaccinated against COVID-19 and following recommendations to protect yourself and others will offer the best protection from COVID-19. Getting vaccinated is one of many steps you can take to protect yourself and others from COVID-19. Protection from COVID-19 is critically important because for some people, COVID-19 can cause severe illness or death.
Stopping a pandemic requires using all the tools available. Vaccines work with your immune system so your body will be ready to fight the virus if you are exposed. After you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, you may be able to start doing some things that you had stopped doing because of the pandemic. But we’re still learning how vaccines will affect the spread of COVID-19. After you’ve been fully vaccinated against COVID-19, you should keep taking precautions in public places or when you are with unvaccinated people from more than one household.

Jesus chose six men to follow him. He chose Simon, whom he named Peter. He also chose Andrew, James, John, Philip, and Nathanael. These were his first six disciples.
One day, as Jesus was walking along with his disciples, he saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at his booth. Levi was a Jewish man who collected taxes for the Roman government.
Jesus spoke to Levi, saying, “Follow me, and be my disciple.” So Levi got up, left everything and followed Jesus. Levi was also known as Matthew.
Later, Matthew invited Jesus and his disciples to eat dinner in his home. He also invited many tax collectors and other disreputable sinners to sit and dine with Jesus and his disciples.
When the teachers of religious law, the Pharisees, saw Jesus eating with tax collectors and other sinners, they did not approve.
They said to Jesus’ disciples, “Why does your teacher eat with such people?”
When Jesus heard this, he said, “People who are well do not need a doctor, but only those who are sick. I did not come to invite people who think they are already righteous to be my followers. I came to invite people who know they are sinners.”
News about Jesus spread, so crowds of people came to hear him and for him to heal them of their sicknesses.
One day Jesus went up into the hills to pray. He prayed to God all night.
When morning came, he called all his disciples to him and chose twelve of them. He called these twelve men ‘apostles’.
These are the twelve apostles Jesus chose: Simon whom Jesus named Peter, and his brother, Andrew; and James and his brother, John. Jesus called James and John “Sons of Thunder.”
Jesus also chose Philip and Bartholomew, and Matthew, the tax collector who was also known as Levi, and Thomas, who was called the Twin, and another James who was the son of Alphaeus.
And Jesus chose another Simon who was called the Zealot, and Thaddaeus, who was the son of James, who was also known as Judas.
And he chose another man named Judas who was Judas Iscariot. He was the man who later betrayed Jesus.
Jesus chose these twelve men to be with him and to send out to preach. He gave them authority to cast out evil spirits. He also gave them power to heal the sick.

Jésus choisit six hommes pour le suivre. Il choisit Simon, qu’il nomme Pierre. Il choisit aussi André, Jacques, Jean, Philippe et Nathanaël. Ce sont les premiers six disciples.
Un jour Jésus et ses disciples passent devant le bureau où les Juifs paient les impôts au gouvernement romain. Jésus voit un collecteur d’impôts assis là. C’était un homme juif appelé Lévi.
Jésus dit à Lévi : « Suis-moi et sois mon disciple. » Lévi se lève, il laisse tout et il suit Jésus. Lévi était aussi connu sous le nom de Matthieu.
Plus tard, Matthieu invite Jésus et ses disciples à prendre un repas dans sa maison. Il invite également beaucoup de collecteurs d’impôts et de gens connus pour leurs péchés au repas et ils viennent s’asseoir et manger avec Jésus et les disciples.
Des Pharisiens, maîtres de la loi religieuse, sont là. Ils voient que Jésus mange avec les collecteurs d’impôts et d’autres pécheurs, et ils désapprouvent de cela.
Ils disent aux disciples de Jésus : « Pourquoi votre maître mange-t-il avec les collecteurs d’impôts et les pécheurs ? »
Jésus les entend et dit : « Les gens en bonne santé n’ont pas besoin de médecin. Ce sont les malades qui en ont besoin. Je ne suis pas venu pour inviter ceux qui se croient justes. Je suis venu inviter ceux qui se reconnaissent pécheurs. »
Les gens parlent de plus en plus de Jésus, et des foules nombreuses se rassemblent pour l’écouter et pour qu’il les guérisse de leurs maladies.
Un jour, Jésus monte sur une montagne pour prier. Il passe toute la nuit à prier Dieu.
Au matin, Jésus appelle tous ses disciples et choisit douze parmi eux. Il les a aussi appelés apôtres.
Voici les douze apôtres que Jésus choisit : « Simon, que Jésus nomme Pierre, et son frère André. Jacques et son frère, Jean. Jésus appelle Jacques et Jean les « hommes qui ressemblent au tonnerre ».
Jésus choisit aussi Philippe, Barthélemy, Matthieu le collecteur d’impôt que l’on appelait aussi Lévi, Thomas, qu’on appelait le jumeau, et Jacques le fils d’Alphée.
Jésus choisit encore Simon, le nationaliste, et Thaddée le fils de Jacques, connu aussi sous le nom de Judas.
Enfin, il choisit Judas Iscariote. C’est l’homme qui va livrer Jésus.
Jésus choisit ces douze hommes pour les avoir avec lui et pour les envoyer annoncer la Bonne Nouvelle. Il leur donne le pouvoir de chasser les esprits mauvais et de guérir les malades.

The Israelites moved from one place to another as the Lord directed them.
At the Lord’s command, they left the desert of Sin. That was the place where the Lord had first given them quail and manna for food.
Exactly two months after the Israelites left Egypt, they came to the desert of Sinai. They set up camp at the base of Mount Sinai.
Then Moses climbed up the mountain to talk with God. The Lord called to him from the mountain. God told Moses to say to the people of Israel,
“You saw what I did to the Egyptians. You saw how I carried you as an eagle carries her young on her wings, and brought you here to me.”
“Now obey my voice and keep my covenant.”
“If you obey all that I command you, you will be my own people, my special possession over whom I will rule. You will be a kingdom of priests, and a holy nation.”
So Moses went down and told the people everything that God had told him to say to them. Then all the Israelites agreed and said, “We will do everything that God has told us to do.”
Then Moses reported this back to God, and the Lord spoke to Moses again.
He said, “I will come to you from inside a thick cloud. When I speak to you, the people will hear it.”
“From then on, they will believe what you say. Tell the people to prepare for my arrival.”
“They should purify themselves and wash their clothes today and tomorrow.”
“On the day after tomorrow, I will come down on Mount Sinai in a thick cloud in front of all the people.”
“Mark a boundary around the base of the mountain and tell the people not to go up on the mountain or even get near it.”
“If anyone besides you, Moses, steps up on the mountain, that person must die.”
Then Moses came down the mountain and told the people to purify themselves and get ready to worship God.
He said, “Be ready by the day after tomorrow. When you hear a long, loud trumpet sound, we will go to the mountain.”
On the third day, during the morning, there was thunder and lightning and a dark cloud on the mountain. A trumpet sounded very loudly. The people in the camp were afraid.
Then Moses led the people out of the camp to meet with God. They all stood at the base of the mountain. Then the whole mountain trembled violently. And the trumpet sound grew louder and louder.
Moses spoke, and the Lord answered him. The Lord came down to the top of the mountain. Then the Lord called Moses back up to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.

021 Moïse sur le mont Sinaï





Dieu a fait sortir les Israélites d’Egypte où ils étaient tenus en esclavage. Dieu a agi contre les Egyptiens avec des grands miracles.
Après leur sortie d’Egypte, les Israélites cheminent d’un endroit à l’autre dans le désert. C’est Dieu qui les dirige.
Quand Dieu leur demande, ils quittent le désert de Sin. C’est là que le Seigneur leur a donné des cailles et de la manne comme nourriture pour la première fois.
Deux mois exactement après leur départ d’Égypte, les Israélites arrivent au désert du Sinaï et installent leur camp près du mont Sinaï.
Moïse monte sur la montagne pour rencontrer Dieu. Le Seigneur lui donne un message pour les Israélites.
Dieu dit: « Vous avez vu comment j’ai traité les Égyptiens. Vous avez vu comment je vous ai amenés ici. Je vous ai portés comme un aigle porte ses petits sur ses ailes. »
Alors Dieu fait une alliance, un accord, avec les Israélites. Il dit :
«  Si vous m’obéissez et respectez mon alliance, vous serez mon peuple. Le monde entier est à moi, mais vous serez pour moi un bien précieux – un royaume de sacrificateurs et une peuple qui m’est réservé. »
Moïse descend de la montagne et transmet toutes les paroles du Seigneur aux responsables du peuple. Alors les Israélites disent tous ensemble : « Nous ferons tout ce que le Seigneur nous a demandé de faire. »
Moïse rapporte à Dieu la réponse du peuple. Alors Dieu dit à Moïse :
« Je vais descendre vers toi dans un épais nuage de fumée pour que le peuple entende quand je parle avec toi. »
« Alors ils croiront tes paroles. Demande-leur de se préparer pour mon arrivée. »
«  Il faut qu’ils se rendent purs et lavent leur vêtements aujourd’hui et demain. »
« Dans deux jours, je vais descendre sur la montagne Sinaï devant tout le peuple, dans un épais nuage. »
« Trace une limite autour de la montagne. Avertis le peuple de ne pas monter sur la montagne et de ne pas trop s’en approcher. »
« Si quelqu’un d’autre que toi, Moïse, monte sur la montagne, il doit être mis à mort. »
Alors Moïse descend de la montagne et dit aux Israélites de se préparer pour adorer Dieu.
Il leur dit : «  Soyez prêts après-demain. Quand la corne de bélier sonne, nous devons aller vers la montagne. »
Le troisième jour, tôt le matin, il y a des coups de tonnerre et des éclairs. Un épais nuage de fumée couvre la montagne et on entend le son très puissant d’une corne de bélier. Le peuple tremble de peur.
Alors Moïse fait sortir le peuple du camp pour rencontrer Dieu. Ils s’arrêtent au bas de la montagne. Alors la montagne tremble très fort et le son de la corne de bélier devient de plus en plus fort.
Dieu appelle Moïse et lui demande de monter au sommet de la montagne.

121 Jairus' Daughter Raised and a Woman Healed





When Jesus was back in Capernaum by the seaside, the people crowded around him.
Then a man named Jairus arrived. He was an official in the local synagogue.
So Jesus and his disciples went with Jairus. And many people followed along crowding closely around Jesus.
When she heard about Jesus, she came up behind him in the crowd, thinking, “If I can just touch his robe I will be healed!”
Immediately, Jesus knew that power to heal had gone out from him. So he turned around in the crowd and asked, “Who touched me?”
His disciples responded, “Look at this crowd all around you. How can you ask, ‘Who touched me?’” But Jesus kept on looking around to see who had done it.
Then the frightened woman came forward, fell to her knees in front of Jesus, and told him what she had done.
Jesus said to her, “My daughter, your faith has made you well. Go in peace! Your suffering is over.”
While Jesus was still speaking to the woman, messengers arrived from the home of Jairus. “Your daughter is dead,” they reported. “There’s no use in troubling the teacher now.”
But when Jesus heard that, he said to Jairus, "Do not be afraid. Just believe in me and she will live again."
Jesus did not let anyone go with him to Jairus’ house except Peter, James and John.
All the people at Jairus’ house were crying loudly to show that they were very sad because his daughter had died.
Jesus went inside and said to them, “Stop crying! She is not dead. She is just sleeping.” The people laughed at Jesus.
But Jesus made them all leave, and he took the girl’s father and mother and his three disciples into the room where the girl was lying.
Jesus took hold of her hand and spoke to her, saying, “Child, get up!”
And the daughter, who was twelve years old, immediately stood up and walked around!
Jesus told them to give her something to eat. Her parents were amazed, but Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone else what had happened.

One day, Peter asked Jesus, “Master, how many times should I forgive my brother when he sins against me? Up to seven times?” Jesus said, “Not seven times, but seventy times seven!” By this, Jesus meant that we should always forgive. Then Jesus told this story.
Jesus said, “The kingdom of God is like a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants. One of his servants owed a huge debt worth 200,000 years’ wages.”
“Since the servant could not pay the debt, the king said, ‘Sell this man and his family as slaves to make payment on his debt.’”
“The servant fell on his knees before the king and said, ‘Please be patient with me, and I will pay the full amount that I owe you.’ The king felt pity for the servant, so he canceled all of his debt and let him go.”
“But when the servant went out from the king, he found a fellow servant who owed him a debt worth four months’ wages. The servant grabbed his fellow servant and said, ‘Pay me the money that you owe me!’”
“The fellow servant fell on his knees and said, ‘Please be patient with me, and I will pay the full amount that I owe you.’ But instead, the servant threw his fellow servant into prison until he could pay the debt.”
“Some other servants saw what had happened and were greatly disturbed. They went to the king and told him everything.”
“The king called the servant and said, ‘You wicked servant! I forgave your debt because you begged me. You should have done the same.’ The king was so angry that he threw the wicked servant into prison until he could pay back all of his debt.”
Then Jesus said, “This is what my heavenly Father will do to every one of you if you do not forgive your brother from your heart.”

29. La Parabole du Serviteur sans Pitié



29. La Parabole du Serviteur sans Pitié





Un jour Pierre demanda à Jésus: “Seigneur, combien de fois pardonnerai-je à mon frère, lorsqu’il pèchera contre moi? Jusqu’à sept fois?” Jésus répondit: “Pas jusqu’à sept fois, mais jusqu’à soixante-dix fois sept fois!” Jésus voulait dire que l’on doit toujours pardonner. Puis Jésus raconta cette parabole.
Il dit: “Le Royaume de Dieu est semblable à un roi qui voulait que ses serviteurs lui rendent compte . L’un de ses serviteurs avait une dette qui s’élevait à plusieurs vies d’années de salaire.
Comme le serviteur n’avait pas de quoi payer sa dette, le roi dit: “Vendez cet homme et sa famille comme esclaves pour que sa dette soit payée.”
“Le serviteur se prosterna devant le roi et dit:”‘Fais preuve de patience envers moi, et je te paierai tout ce que je te dois.’ Le roi eut de la compassion pour le serviteur, annula toute sa dette et le laissa partir."
“Mais quand le serviteur quitta le roi, il rencontra un autre serviteur qui avait envers lui une dette équivalente à quatre mois de salaire. Le premier serviteur saisit l’homme et lui dit:”Rends-moi ce que tu me dois."
“Le second serviteur le supplia, disant:”Fais preuve de patience envers moi et je payerai toute ma dette“. Mais le premier serviteur refusa et le jeta en prison jusqu’à ce qu’il eut payé la dette.”
“Ses compagnons, ayant vu ce qui s’était passé, furent profondément attristés. Ils allèrent tout raconter au roi.”
’Le roi appela le serviteur et lui dit, “Méchant serviteur! Je t’avais remis en entier ta dette, parce que tu m’avais supplié. Tu aurais dû faire la même chose.” Le roi, fâché, le jeta en prison jusqu’à ce qu’il eût payé toute sa dette."
Alors, Jésus dit: “C’est ainsi que mon Père Céleste vous traitera, si chacun de vous ne pardonne pas à son frère de tout son cœur.”

Gideon hid in the darkness near the enemy camp. He overheard a man telling his companion about a dream.
His companion answered, “Your dream can only mean one thing—God has given victory to Gideon and the armies of the Israelites.”
When Gideon heard this, he worshiped the Lord. Then he returned to the Israelite camp and prepared his men to fight against the Midianites.
Gideon followed God’s directions and divided his 300 men into three equal groups. Then he gave each man a ram’s horn trumpet and a clay jar with a torch in it.
The three groups of Israelites took up positions surrounding the enemy camp. Then Gideon said to them, “Keep your eyes on me and do just what I do.”
At midnight, just after the Midianite guard was changed, Gideon and the 100 men with him blew their ram’s horns and broke their clay jars.
Then all the rest of the Israelite soldiers blew their trumpets and broke the clay jars. Then their torches burned brightly in the darkness.
With their torches in their left hands and trumpets in their right hands, all the Israelites shouted, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
Then the Midianites panicked. The Lord caused the warriors in the camp to attack each other and those who were not killed ran far away.
Then Gideon immediately sent messengers throughout Israel and the hill country saying, “Come down to chase and attack the Midianites”.
Gideon’s men were now tired from chasing the Midianites. They were also very hungry. So Gideon asked the people of Succoth for food for his men.
But the people of Succoth refused to give Gideon and his men any food. They were afraid that the Midianites might win the battle and then come and punish them for helping the Israelites.
By this time, they had killed 120,000 Midianite soldiers. There were only 15,000 warriors left.
Then in a surprise attack at Karkor, Gideon’s men defeated the last 15,000 Midianites. They took the Midianite kings Zebah and Zalmunna captive and later Gideon executed them.
Afterwards, Gideon returned to Succoth where the people refused to help him while in battle. He commanded his men to use thorns and briars to punish the leaders there and tear down the tower of Penuel, also killing the men of the town.
After this victory, the Israelites said to Gideon, “Be our ruler because you have saved us from our enemies, the Midianites. And after you die your sons can then rule over us.”
Gideon replied, “God is your only ruler.” Then Gideon said, “I want each of you to give me a gold earring from the plunder you took from the Midianites.” The people were glad to do that.
Gideon made an image from the gold and placed it in his hometown of Ophrah.
Soon the Israelites sinned against God by worshiping this object. This became a very serious problem for Gideon and his family.
After defeating the Midianites, the people of Israel lived in peace for forty years.
When Gideon died the people of Israel forgot God and began to worship Baal again.
039 God Gives Victory to Gideon.original_text:
039 La victoire de Gédéon sur les Madianites



039 La victoire de Gédéon sur les Madianites





Dans l’obscurité de la nuit, Gédéon s’approche du camp de ses ennemis, les Madianites, et se cache. Il entend un homme raconter un rêve à un camarade.
Son camarade répond : « Ton rêve ne peut signifier qu’une seule chose – Dieu a décidé de livrer tout notre camp à Gédéon et à l’armée des Israélites. »
Quand Gédéon entend cela, il se met à genoux pour adorer le Seigneur. Puis il revient au camp des Israélites et prépare ses hommes à combattre les Madianites.
Gédéon suit les instructions de Dieu et divise ses 300 hommes en trois groupes égaux. Il donne à chaque homme une corne de bélier, un pot vide et une torche à mettre dans le pot.
Les trois groupes d’Israélites se positionnent autour du camp ennemi. Et Gédéon leur dit : « Vous regarderez de mon côté et vous ferez comme moi ! »
Au milieu de la nuit, quand les Madianites ont remplacé les gardes du camp, Gédéon et son groupe d’homme sonnent leurs cornes de bélier et cassent les pots contenant leurs torches.
Puis le reste des Israélites sonnent leurs cornes de bélier et cassent leurs pots. Alors les torchent des Israélites brillent dans l’obscurité.
Avec les torches dans la main gauche et les cornes dans la main droite, les Israélites crient : « Attaquons ! Pour le Seigneur et pour Gédéon ! »
Alors les Madianites sont pris de panique. Le Seigneur fait en sorte qu’ils se tuent entre eux dans le camp, et ceux qui restent en vie prennent la fuite.
Gédéon envoie des messagers dans la région montagneuse d’Éfraïm : « Descendez pour poursuivre et attaquer les Madianites. »
Les hommes de Gédéon sont épuisés par la poursuite des Madianites et ils ont faim. Alors Gédéon demande aux habitants des villages de Soukoth et de Penouel de donner à manger à ses hommes.
Mais les habitants de Soukoth et de Penouel refusent de leur donner à manger. Ils ont peur que les Madianites gagnent la bataille et reviennent les punir pour l’aide qu’ils ont donné aux Israélites.
Jusque-là, 120 000 soldats Madianites sont morts, et il n’en reste plus que
15 000.
A Carcor, Gédéon et ses hommes font une attaque surprise et battent le restant de l’armée Madianite qui se croyait en lieu sûr. Gédéon capture les rois Madianites Zéba et Salmounna et les exécute par la suite.
Après cela, Gédéon retourne à Soukoth et à Pénouel, les villes dont les habitants ont refusé d’aider les Israélites pendant la bataille. Gédéon frappe les chefs de Soukoth avec des branches d’épines et des chardons, et il tue les habitants de la ville.
Après la victoire sur les Madianites, les Israélites disent à Gédéon : « Sois notre chef, puis ton fils et le fils de ton fils après toi, parce que tu nous as délivrés du pouvoir des Madianites. »
Mais Gédéon refuse et leur dit : « C’est le Seigneur et lui seul qui sera votre chef. » Ensuite, Gédéon leur demande: « Prenez chacun un anneau d’or de ce que vous avez pris aux Madianites et donnez-les moi. » Le peuple est d’accord de faire cela.
Avec cet or, Gédéon fait un objet qu’il place dans son village, à Ofra.
Les Israélites viennent à cet endroit pour adorer l’objet et font ainsi ce qui est mal aux yeux de Dieu. Cet objet devient alors un piège pour Gédéon et sa famille.
Après la défaite des Madianites, le peuple d’Israël connaît la paix pendant 40 ans.
Mais après la mort de Gédéon, les Israélites ne sont plus fidèles au Seigneur. En effet, le Seigneur les a délivrés de leurs ennemis. Mais ils oublient le Seigneur et adorent de nouveau le dieu Baal.

Chicken and Millipede



Chicken and Millipede






Chicken and Millipede were friends. But they were always competing with each other. One day they decided to play football to see who the best player was.


They went to the football field and started their game. Chicken was fast, but Millipede was faster. Chicken kicked far, but Millipede kicked further. Chicken started to feel grumpy.


They decided to play a penalty shoot-out. First Millipede was goal keeper. Chicken scored only one goal. Then it was the chicken’s turn to defend the goal.


Millipede kicked the ball and scored. Millipede dribbled the ball and scored. Millipede headed the ball and scored. Millipede scored five goals.


Chicken was furious that she lost. She was a very bad loser. Millipede started laughing because his friend was making such a fuss.


Chicken was so angry that she opened her beak wide and swallowed the millipede.


As Chicken was walking home, she met Mother Millipede. Mother Millipede asked, “Have you seen my child?” Chicken didn’t say anything. Mother Millipede was worried.


Then Mother Millipede heard a tiny voice. “Help me mom!” cried the voice. Mother Millipede looked around and listened carefully. The voice came from inside the chicken.


Mother Millipede shouted, “Use your special power my child!” Millipedes can make a bad smell and a terrible taste. Chicken began to feel ill.


Chicken burped. Then she swallowed and spat. Then she sneezed and coughed. And coughed. The millipede was disgusting!


Chicken coughed until she coughed out the millipede that was in her stomach. Mother Millipede and her child crawled up a tree to hide.


From that time, chickens and millipedes were enemies.

La poule et le millepatte



La poule et le millepatte






La poule et le millepatte étaient amis. Mais ils étaient toujours en compétition l'un contre l'autre. Un jour, ils décidèrent de jouer au football pour voir qui était le meilleur joueur.


Ils allèrent au terrain de football et commencèrent à jouer. La poule était rapide, mais le millepatte était encore plus rapide. La poule envoyait le ballon loin, mais le millepatte l'envoyait encore plus loin. La poule commençait à être de mauvaise humeur.


Ils décidèrent de tirer des pénaltys. Au début, le millepatte était gardien de but. La poule marqua un seul but. Puis ce fut au tour de la poule d'être le gardien de but.


Le millepatte tira dans le ballon et marqua. Le millepatte dribbla avec le ballon et marqua. Le millepatte fit une tête avec le ballon et marqua. Le millepatte marqua cinq buts.


La poule était furieuse d'avoir perdu. C'était était une très mauvaise perdante. Le millepatte commença à rire parce que son amie faisait tout une histoire.


La poule était tellement en colère qu'elle ouvrit un large bec et avala le millepatte.


Alors que la poule rentrait à la maison, elle rencontra la maman millepatte. La maman millepatte demanda, "as-tu vu mon enfant?" La poule ne répondit pas.
La maman millepatte était inquiète.


Puis la maman millepatte entendit une petite voix. "Aide-moi maman!" Criait la voix. La maman millepatte regarda autour et écouta attentivement. La voix venait de l'intérieur de la poule.


La maman millepatte s'écria "Utilise tes pouvoirs spéciaux mon enfant!" Les millepattes peuvent faire une mauvaise odeur et donner un mauvais goût. La poule commença à se sentir mal.


La poule fit un rot. Puis elle déglutit et cracha. Puis elle éternua et toussa. Et toussa. Le millepatte était dégoûtant!


La poule toussa jusqu'à ce qu'elle recrache le millepatte qui était dans son estomac. La maman millepatte et son enfant rampèrent jusqu'à un arbre pour se cacher.


Depuis ce temps, les poules et des millepattes sont ennemis.

04. Laa A Zɔɔ Nyaa Nεε Ibirayi.text:
Many years after the flood, there were again many people in the world, and they all spoke the same language. Instead of filling the earth as God had commanded, they gathered together and built a city.
They were very proud, and they did not care about what God said. They even began building a tall tower to reach heaven. God saw that if they all kept working together to do evil, they could do many more sinful things.
So God changed their language into many different languages and spread the people out all over the world. The city they had begun to build was called Babel, which means, “confused.”
Hundreds of years later, God spoke to a man named Abram.   God told him, “Leave your country and family and go to the land I will show you. I will bless you and make you a great nation. I will make your name great. I will bless those who bless you and curse those who curse you. All families on earth will be blessed because of you.”
So Abram obeyed God. He took his wife, Sarai, together with all of his servants and everything he owned and went to the land God showed him, the land of Canaan.
When Abram arrived in Canaan, God said, “Look all around you. I will give to you and your descendants all the land that you can see as an inheritance.” Then Abram settled in the land.
One day, Abram met Melchizedek, the priest of God Most High. Melchizedek blessed Abram and said, “May God Most High who owns heaven and earth bless Abram.” Then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of all he owned.
Many years went by, but Abram and Sarai still did not have a son. God spoke to Abram and promised again that he would have a son and as many descendants as the stars in the sky. Abram believed God’s promise. God declared that Abram was righteous because he believed in God’s promise.
Then God made a covenant with Abram. A covenant is an agreement between two parties. God said, “I will give you a son from your own body. I give the land of Canaan to your descendants.” But Abram still did not have a son.

04. L'Alliance de Dieu avec Abraham



04. L'Alliance de Dieu avec Abraham





Plusieurs années après le déluge, il y avait à nouveau beaucoup d’hommes dans le monde et tous parlaient la même langue. Au lieu de remplir la terre comme Dieu l’avait ordonné, ils s’étaient rassemblés et avaient bâti une ville.
Ils étaient très orgueilleux, et n’avaient pas écouté Dieu. Ils avaient même commencé à bâtir une grande tour qui toucherait le ciel. Dieu réalisa que s’ils continuaient à travailler ensemble pour faire du mal, ils pourraient faire des choses pires qu’auparavant. .
Alors Dieu changea leur langue en plusieurs langues différentes et les dispersa partout dans le monde. La ville qu’ils avaient commencée à bâtir s’appelait Babel, ce qui veut dire “confus.”
Des centaines d’années plus tard, Dieu parla à un homme qui s’appelait Abram. Dieu lui dit: “Laisse ton pays et ta famille et va vers le pays que je te montrerai. Je te bénirai et je ferai de toi une grande nation. Je rendrai ton nom grand. Je bénirai ceux qui te béniront et je maudirai ceux qui te maudiront. Toutes les familles de la terre seront bénies en toi.”
Alors Abram obéit à Dieu. Il prit sa femme Saraï, tous ses domestiques et tous les biens qu’il possédait et ils partirent dans le pays que Dieu lui avait montré, le pays de Canaan.
Quand Abram fut arrivé au pays de Canaan, Dieu dit: “Regarde autour de toi. Je te donnerai en héritage, ainsi qu’à tes descendants, tout le pays que tu vois.” Alors Abram s’installa dans ce pays.
Un jour, de retour d’une guerre, Abram fit la connaissance de Melchisédek, le prêtre du Dieu Très-Haut. Melchisédek bénit Abram et lui dit: “Que le Dieu Très-Haut à qui appartient le ciel et la terre te bénisse.” Puis Abram donna à Melchisédek un dixième de tout ce qu’il venait de gagner à la guerre.
Plusieurs années passèrent, mais Abram et Saraï n’avaient toujours pas de fils. Dieu parla à Abram et lui promit encore une fois qu’il aura un fils et une descendance aussi nombreuse que les étoiles dans le ciel. Abram crut en la promesse de Dieu qui le déclara juste à cause de sa foi.
Puis Dieu fit une Alliance avec Abram. Une alliance est un accord entre deux parties. Dieu dit: “Je te donnerai un fils qui viendra de ton corps. Je donne le pays de Canaan à tes descendants”, mais Abram n’avait toujours pas de fils.

Diarrhea\nHow to treat it at home.text:
Diarrhea
How to treat it at home



Diarrhea
How to treat it at home





Diarrhea
How to treat it at home
Diarrhea can lead to the death of a child if not treated early. Some 5,000,000 children die from it annually. The most serious conditions that arise from diarrhea are dehydration and malnutrition. Dehydration means that the child does not have enough water left in his body. It happens when the body loses more liquid than it takes in. People of any age can become dehydrated. However, it develops more quickly and is most dangerous in small children. A dehydrated person has a dry mouth and tongue, sunken eyes, weight loss, absence of tears, etc.
If you give the child plenty to drink at home, you can prevent the diarrhea from becoming serious. Give the child liquids like rice water, guava leaf tea, the water that vegetables have been cooked in (carrots, huckleberry, greens), ORS packet, or even plain water. Avoid any food or drink which has grease or fat in it. If the child refuses to drink or vomits, stay patient and keep trying.
Give these liquids as follows:
—  children less than 2 years, 1/2 cup
—  older children, a full cup
Give these quantities after every stool and whenever they are thirsty. Give it to young children to drink with a cup and a spoon. Do not use a baby bottle because it is harder to keep clean. It is more likely to cause an infection. Give them as much as they want to drink.  
A sick child needs food. This is especially true for young children or for anyone who is thin and weak. He needs body-building foods and energy foods all the time he is sick—and also when he gets well.
 Although giving food may cause more frequent stools at first, it can save his life. Feed a child with diarrhea small amounts often to encourage digestion and tolerance of foods. After the diarrhea is finished, give the child more to eat than normal. He will regain his weight that way.
Some body-building foods (proteins) are chicken, eggs, meat cooked without adding fat or grease, soybeans, beans cooked and mashed, and fish. Some energy foods are rice, bananas, papaya, potatoes, and cooked, mashed corn.
Those sick with diarrhea should avoid foods and liquids cooked in fat, most raw fruits, greasy foods, highly seasoned foods, or any alcoholic drinks.
Breast feeding is essential for children and should be given very often during diarrhea. Mothers also need to eat body-building foods and energy foods to keep producing enough milk for the child. Breast feeding is the most complete meal for a child. It protects the baby against infection. It is always ready to give to the baby and needs no preparation. It never goes sour or bad. Breast feeding ties mother and child together. It is cheap. You do not need to buy anything.
Take the child to a health center in case of the following:
—  the child is very weak
—  he has a fever
—  his stools are many
—  his stools have blood
—  he is vomiting a lot
—  his eyes are sunken
—  his fontanels are sunken
—  he is losing weight
—  the child does not get better after two days of treatment at home.
In these cases rush him to the nearest health center.
After returning from the health center, continue treatment as instructed and until the child is well. To prevent reoccurrence of diarrhea, try the following inexpensive strategies:
—   breast feed your young child
—   drink clean water which has been boiled or purified in bright sunlight for several hours
—   wash hands before preparing food, before eating, before breast feeding a child, after going to toilet
—   use a latrine
—   dispose of a young child’s stool in the latrine too or bury it
—   vaccinate children, particularly against measles
—   eat body-building foods (soybeans, beans, fish, meat, eggs) and energy foods (rice, millet, corn) every day.

La Diarrhée Comment la traiter à la maison



La Diarrhée Comment la traiter à la maison

La Diarrhée
Comment la traiter à la maison
Toute diarrhée est dangereuse et peut mener à la mort de l’enfant si elle n’est pas traitée à temps. Environ 5.000.000 d’enfants meurent chaque année de la diarrhée. Les conséquences les plus sérieuses de la diarrhée sont la déshydratation et la malnutrition. La déshydratation signifie que l’enfant n’a plus assez d’eau dans le corps. Cela se passe lorsque le corps perd plus d’eau qu’il n’en reçoit. Des personnes de tous âges peuvent souffrir de déshydratation. Elle se développe cependant de façon plus dangereuse et plus rapide chez les enfants en bas âge. Une personne déshydratée a la bouche et la langue sèche, les yeux enfoncés dans les orbites, elle perd du poids et n’a plus de larmes.
Si vous donnez beaucoup de liquide à votre enfant dès l’apparition des premières selles liquides, vous pouvez empêcher que la diarrhée ne devienne dangereuse. Donnez à votre enfant des liquides tels que  de l’eau de riz, des infusions de feuilles de goyave, l’eau dans laquelle vous avez cuit des végétaux (carottes, feuilles, etc.), des sachets SRO (sels de réhydratation orale) ou même de l’eau simple. Evitez toute nourriture ou boisson contenant des matières grasses. Si l’enfant refuse de boire, soyez patient et continuez à essayer de le faire boire. S’il vomit, attendez quelques minutes puis recommencez lentement, par petites cuillerées.
Donnez ces liquides de la façon suivante :
—  enfants de moins de deux ans : une demi-tasse
—  enfants de deux ans ou plus : une tasse
Donnez cette quantité de liquide après chaque selle ou quand l’enfant a soif. Donnez à boire avec une tasse et une cuillère, même aux jeunes enfants. N’utilisez pas de biberons car il est plus difficile de les maintenir propres, et ils sont, par conséquent, plus susceptibles de causer des infections. Donnez-leur à boire autant qu’ils le désirent.
Un enfant malade a besoin de nourriture. Ceci est tout
particulièrement vrai pour les jeunes enfants et pour toute personne maigre et faible. Il a besoin de nourriture qui reconstruit le corps et lui donne de l’énergie pendant tout le temps de la maladie, mais aussi quand il commence à aller mieux. Bien que le fait de donner de la nourriture va provoquer des selles plus fréquentes au début, cela peut sauver sa vie. Bien que le fait de donner de la nourriture va provoquer des selles plus fréquentes au début, cela peut sauver sa vie. Si l’enfant souffre de diarrhée, nourrissez-le souvent, par petites quantités, afin de stimuler la digestion et la tolérance de la nourriture.

Lorsque la diarrhée est terminée, donnez à l’enfant plus de nourriture que d’habitude. Ainsi il regagnera le poids qu’il a perdu.
On trouve les éléments nutritifs qui reconstruisent le corps (les protéines) dans le poulet, les œufs, la viande cuite sans adjonction de graisse ou d’huile, les grains de soja, les haricots cuits et écrasés, le poisson. Les aliments qui donnent de l’énergie sont le riz, les bananes, les papayes, les pommes de terre, l’avoine, le maïs cuit et réduit en purée.
Ceux qui souffrent de diarrhée devraient éviter la nourriture et les liquides cuits dans la graisse, la plupart des fruits crus, les aliments gras ou très épicés, les boissons alcoolisées.
Il est essentiel de nourrir les enfants au sein et il faudrait les allaiter souvent lorsqu’ils souffrent de diarrhée. Les mères aussi ont besoin de manger de la nourriture qui construit le corps et donne de l’énergie, afin d’avoir suffisamment de lait pour nourrir l’enfant. Le lait maternel est le repas le plus complet pour l’enfant. Il protège l’enfant des infections. C’est un repas qui est toujours prêt et ne demande aucune préparation. Il ne s’altère pas et ne devient jamais rance. L’allaitement maternel unit la mère et l’enfant. C’est bon marché et vous n’avez pas besoin d’acheter quoi que ce soit.
Amenez l’enfant au centre de santé si l’un des signes suivants se présente :
—   l’enfant est très faible
—   il a la fièvre
—   les selles sont fréquentes
—   il y a du sang dans les selles
—   il vomit beaucoup
—   les yeux sont enfoncés dans les orbites
—   la fontanelle est creuse (l’endroit mou sur la tête du bébé́)
—   perte de poids
—   l’enfant ne va pas mieux après deux jours de traitement à la maison.
Lorsque vous rentrez du centre de santé, continuez le traitement selon les instructions que l’on vous aura données jusqu’à ce que l’enfant aille bien. Afin de prévenir une rechute, appliquez les mesures préventives suivantes :
—   nourrissez votre enfant au sein
—   buvez de l’eau propre qui a été bouillie où exposée en plein soleil pendant plusieurs heures
—   lavez-vous les mains avant de commencer à préparer la nourriture
—   utilisez des latrines
—   jetez les selles des jeunes enfants dans les latrines ou enterrez-les
—   vaccinez les jeunes enfants, particulièrement contre la rougeole
—   mangez chaque jour de la nourriture qui construit le corps (grains de soja, haricots, poisson, viande, œufs) et de la nourriture qui donne de l’énergie (riz, mil, maïs).

43. The Church Begins





43. The Church Begins


After Jesus returned to heaven, the disciples stayed in Jerusalem as Jesus had commanded them to do. The believers there constantly gathered together to pray.
Every year, 50 days after the Passover, the Jews celebrated an important day called Pentecost. Pentecost was a time when the Jews celebrated the wheat harvest. Jews came from all over the world to Jerusalem to celebrate Pentecost together. This year, the time for Pentecost came about a week after Jesus had gone back to heaven.
While the believers were all together, suddenly the house where they were was filled with a sound like a strong wind. Then something that looked like flames of fire appeared over the heads of all the believers. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and they began to speak in other languages.
When the people in Jerusalem heard the noise, a crowd came to see what was happening. When the people heard the believers proclaiming the wonderful works of God, they were astonished that they were hearing these things in their own native languages.
Some of the people accused the disciples of being drunk. But Peter stood up and said to them, “Listen to me! These people are not drunk! This fulfills the prophecy made by the prophet Joel in which God said, ‘In the last days, I will pour out my Spirit.’”
“Men of Israel, Jesus was a man who did many mighty signs and wonders by the power of God, as you have seen and already know. But you crucified him!”
“Although Jesus died, God raised him from the dead. This fulfills the prophecy which says, ‘You will not let your Holy One rot in the grave.’ We are witnesses to the fact that God raised Jesus to life again.”
“Jesus is now exalted to the right hand of God the Father. And Jesus has sent the Holy Spirit just as he promised he would do. The Holy Spirit is causing the things that you are now seeing and hearing.”
“You crucified this man, Jesus. But know for certain that God has caused Jesus to become both Lord and Messiah!”

The people listening to Peter were deeply moved by the things that he said. So they asked Peter and the disciples, “Brothers, what should we do?”

Peter answered them, “Every one of you should repent and be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ so that God will forgive your sins. Then he will also give you the gift of the Holy Spirit.”
About 3,000 people believed what Peter said and became disciples of Jesus. They were baptized and became part of the church at Jerusalem.
The disciples continually listened to the teaching of the apostles, spent time together, ate together, and prayed with each other. They enjoyed praising God together and they shared everything they had with each other. Everyone thought well of them. Every day, more people became believers.

43. Le Commencement de l'Église





43. Le Commencement de l'Église


Après l’Ascension de Jésus, les disciples restèrent à Jérusalem comme Il le leur avait prescrit. Les croyants se rassemblaient constamment pour prier.
Chaque année, cinquante jours après la Pâque, les Juifs célébraient une journée de grâce importante, la Pentécôte. Les Juifs de toutes les nations venaient à Jérusalem pour célébrer la Pentécôte ensemble avec les autres croyants. Cette année-là, la Pentécôte avait eu lieu une semaine après que Jésus fût retourné au ciel.
Pendant que les disciples et leurs frères dans la foi étaient rassemblés, soudain, un grand bruit survint du ciel. C’était comme si un coup de vent violent s’abattait sur eux et remplissait toute la maison où ils se trouvaient. A l’instant, des langues de feu leur apparurent et se posèrent sur la tête de chaque disciple et ils furent tous remplis du Saint-Esprit et commencèrent à parler dans différentes langues.
Quand les gens à Jérusalem entendirent ce bruit, ils vinrent nombreux pour voir ce qui se passait. Quand Ils entendirent les disciples proclamer les choses merveilleuses que Dieu avait accomplies, ils furent saisis d’étonnement en les entendant parler dans les différentes représentées à Jérusalem ce jour-là.
Certains accusèrent les disciples d’être ivres, alors Pierre se leva et leur dit: “Ecoutez-moi bien! Ces gens ne sont pas ivres! C’est l’accomplissement de la prophétie annoncée par le prophète Joël. Dieu dit: ‘Dans les derniers jours, je répandrai de mon Esprit sur tous les hommes.’”
"Hommes d’Israël, Jésus, cet homme que vous avez vu accomplir au milieu de vous des miracles, des signes et des actes extraordinaires par la Puissance de Dieu, vous l’avez crucifié."
“Dieu l’a ressuscité. Cela accomplit la prophétie qui disait: ‘Tu ne laisseras pas Ton Saint voir la corruption dans le tombeau.’ Nous sommes témoins que Dieu l’a ressuscité des morts.”
“Jésus est monté au ciel pour siéger à la droite du Père. Il a envoyé le Saint-Esprit comme Il l’avait promis et c’est par lui que vous voyez et entendez ces choses là.”
“Vous avez crucifié cet homme, Jésus. Sachez avec certitude que Dieu l’a fait à la fois Seigneur et Messie.”

Les gens qui écoutaient Pierre étaient profondément touchés par tout ce qu’il disait et lui demandèrent ainsi qu’aux autres disciples: “Frères, que devons-nous faire?”

Pierre répondit: “Chacun doit se répentir et se faire baptiser au nom de Jésus-Christ pour que Dieu pardonne ses péchés et lui donne le Saint-Esprit.”
Environ trois mille personnes eurent foi en ce que Pierre avait dit et devinrent disciples de Jésus. Elles furent baptisées et firent partie de l’église de Jérusalem.
Les disciples qui écoutaient assidûment l’enseignement des apôtres, vivaient, mangeaient ensemble et priaient les uns pour les autres. Ils prenaient plaisir à louer Dieu ensemble et partageaient tout ce qu’ils possédaient. Tous leur étaient favorables. Chaque jour, le nombre des croyants grandissait.

Animals dig a well



It happened one year that the rain didn’t fall. The trees dried up and died. The rivers disappeared and the water evaporated. People and animals began dying from hunger and thirst.
Lion and Elephant as the chief animals got together to discuss the situation.
                                Lion said, “We’re going to end up dying from thirst. Let’s call everyone
                                together and discuss the idea of digging a well. Elephant agreed and went
                                off to spread the news to all the animals.
All the animals except the hare got together to discuss the situation.
                                Lion said, “Look, my brothers and sisters, this year, the rain has not fallen.
                                Everyone is dying from hunger and thirst. Let us now make a plan to dig
                                a well so that we might all be able to drink from it.”
All the animals agreed and immediately grabbed hoes, shovels and picks and started digging. They dug and dug. And they dug some more.
                                Finally they hit water. Lion said, “Why did Hare not come to dig this well?
                                He most certainly will not drink from this water!”
Later Hare came and saw the well. He said, “Tipite, tipite at the well!”
                                He heard nothing. So he went in, drank some water and splashed around for a while.
The next day, when the animals came they saw that their well was a big mess. The water was nothing but mud. They asked, “Who would do such a thing?” Someone said, “I bet it was Hare. When we were digging the well he was nowhere to be found.”
And so the animals decided to leave a guard at the well. They chose Baboon
                        to keep an eye on things. Baboon was at the well when Hare came at night saying, “Tipite! Tipite! by the water!” Baboon replied, “Pitani!”
                        So Hare came over and greeted Baboon, “I have come, my friend, and I bring
                        that which the great ones like to eat!”
                        Baboon replied, “Come, let’s see what it is.”
Hare had some honey. He went over to Baboon, “Yes, my friend, try some of this!” Hare gave him the honey.
                                Then he drew some water from the well and drank it.
                                Just as Hare was leaving, Hyena arrived and he saw Hare.
The next day, Hyena went and told all the animals that Hare had taken water from the well. So they chose Turtle to guard the well.
                                Hare arrived at night, saying, “Tipite by the well!” When he didn’t hear any reply he said: “I am Hare! I’ve come to drink water.”
When Turtle had arrived at the well earlier that night, she had hidden herself among the rocks. She looked just like another rock. As soon as Hare started to go into the water, Turtle grabbed Hare by the leg. Turtle didn’t say a word, she just sat there holding on until the sun came up.
When the animals arrived, they saw that Turtle had captured Hare.
                                They called the rest of the animals to decide what to do with Hare.
                                When all the animals were assembled, Lion asked them, “What shall we do with this Hare?”
Turtle said, “Elephant should grab him with her trunk and beat him on the rocks.” All the other animals agreed. Then Hare said, “O Great Lion, you know that hares don’t die if you hit them on rocks. The Hare will only die if he is thrown into ash.” So Lion told Elephant to throw Hare into ash.
After Hare was completely covered with ash, Elephant picked him up and threw him. When Hare landed he made a big cloud of dust. The dust was everywhere.
When the dust settled, the animals looked around. Hare was gone!
                                They realised that Hare had tricked them again.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Excerpt from the SIL Cameroon Science and Citizenship Levelled, Integrated Reader: Class 1, Book 2
Subject:
                        Science (Health Education)
Content Objectives:
                        The pupils will be able to:
                        •    identify the five senses of the body and their uses.
                        •    appreciate and care for parts of their bodies.
We have five senses: seeing, hearing, smelling, touching, tasting.

We see with our eyes.

We hear with our ears.

We smell with our nose.
We touch with our skin.
We taste with our tongue.
We have five senses: seeing, hearing, smelling, touching, tasting.
Oral Comprehension Questions:
                        1.    Name the five senses.  
                        2.    Which part of your body has the sense of sight?  
                        3.    Which part of your body has the sense of hearing? 
                        4.     Which part of your body has the sense of touch?  
                        5.    Which part of your body has the sense of smell?  
                        6.    Which part of your body has the sense of taste?
                        7.    Our senses can be damaged if we do not care for our bodies. How can you protect your
        eyes?  
                        8.    How can you protect your ears?  
                        9.    How can you protect your skin?  
                        10.  How can you protect your nose?  
                        11.   How can you protect your tongue?
Possible Activities:
                        1.    Do an experiment:  Make a sensory container.  Put small items inside a box, bag or can that pupils could attempt to identify by touch or smell.
                        •    By touch:  Either have pupils reach in, find one item, and name it before pulling it out to look at it, or name a characteristic of an item that you would like a pupils to grasp (for example, something soft, scratchy, smooth, etc.)
                        •    By smell: Put one item into the container ask pupils to close their eyes, and pass the can under their noses.  Can they name the item they have smelled?  How would they describe the smell?
                        2.    Ask the following questions:
                        •    Look around. What do you see? What colours do you see? What do you see that is pretty? What do you see that is ugly?
                        •    Sniff. Can you smell anything? What is something that smells good? What is something that smells bad?
                        •    Listen. What do you hear? What makes a loud sound? What makes a soft sound? What do you like to hear?
                        •    What can you feel? What hurts? What feels good?
                        •    What can you taste? What foods taste sweet? What foods taste bitter? What foods taste salty? What foods taste sour?
