016 The Early Life of Moses


A new Pharaoh ruled in Egypt. He did not know Joseph.
This Pharaoh made all of Jacob’s descendants, the Israelites, his slaves. They were mercilessly oppressed and forced to work for the Egyptians.
So Pharaoh issued a command to all the Egyptian people: “Take every newborn Hebrew boy and throw him into the Nile River.”
During this time, there was an Israelite man named Amram. His wife was named Jochebed. Both were descendants of Jacob’s son, Levi. Jochebed gave birth to her third child—a son.
Jochebed saw what a fine baby boy he was, so she hid him for three months. But then she could not hide him any longer.
She took a basket made of reeds and covered it with tar to make it watertight.
When she finished making the basket, she placed her son in it.
Jochebed placed the basket in the tall grass at the edge of the river. Miriam, the baby's sister, stood some distance away to see what would happen.
Pharaoh’s daughter came down to the river to bathe, while her servants walked along the bank. Suddenly she noticed the basket in the tall grass and sent a slave woman to get it.
The princess opened the basket and saw a baby boy. He was crying, and she felt sorry for him. “This is one of the Hebrew babies,” she said.
Then Miriam, who had been watching all this, came to Pharaoh's daughter. Miriam asked her, “Would you like me to get a Hebrew woman to breastfeed and care for the baby?”
“Please do,” Pharaoh’s daughter answered. So Miriam went and brought the baby's own mother.
Pharaoh’s daughter told Jochebed she would pay her to breastfeed the baby. So Jochebed was able to keep her baby son in her own home without any danger to him.
Later, when the child was old enough, Jochebed took him to Pharaoh’s daughter, who adopted the child as her own son.
The boy became the son of Pharaoh’s daughter. She named him Moses, saying, “I lifted him out of the water.” ‘Moses’ sounds like a Hebrew word that means ‘to lift out’. So Moses was raised in Pharaoh’s household.
But Moses understood that his own people were the Hebrews and that he was not an Egyptian.
One day Moses went out to see where his people lived, and he saw how they were forced to work very hard for the Egyptians.
He saw an Egyptian man beating a Hebrew man, one of his own people. Moses looked in every direction and he did not see anyone watching.
So he killed the Egyptian and hid his body in the sand.
The next day Moses went out and saw two Hebrews fighting each other.
Moses wanted to stop their fighting, but one of the men said, “Who made you our ruler and judge? Are you going to kill me just as you killed that Egyptian?”
So Moses was afraid because people knew what he had done.
When Pharaoh heard about what Moses had done, he was very angry and tried to have someone kill Moses. But Moses fled out of Egypt to the land of Midian.
One day, when Moses was sitting by a well, seven daughters of Jethro, the priest of Midian, came to get water from the well, and fill the troughs for their father's sheep and goats.
As the women tried to get water, some shepherds came and started to chase them away. Moses saw what was happening.
So he rescued Jethro's daughters and helped them get water for their animals.
When they returned to their father, he asked, “Why have you come back so early today?”  “An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds,” they answered, “and he even drew water for us and watered our animals.”
“Where is he?” Jethro asked his daughters. “Why did you leave the man out there? Go and invite him to eat with us.” So Moses decided to live with them in the land of Midian.
Moses married Jethro's daughter, Zipporah; and they had two sons, Gershom and Eliezer.
Some years later the Pharaoh died. But the next Pharaoh also treated the Israelites very cruelly as slaves. The Israelites cried out to God for help and God heard them.

One day, Peter and John were going to the Temple. As they approached the Temple gate, they saw a crippled man who was begging for money.
Peter looked at the lame man and said, “I do not have any money to give you. But I will give you what I do have. In the name of Jesus, get up and walk!”
Immediately, God healed the lame man, and he began to walk and jump around, and to praise God. The people in the courtyard of the Temple were amazed.

The leaders of the Temple were very upset by what Peter and John were saying. So they arrested them and put them into prison. But many of the people believed Peter’s message, and the number of men who believed in Jesus grew to about 5,000.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

The Roman governor, Pilate, believed Jesus was innocent. But to appease the religious leaders and to prevent the crowd from rioting, Pilate sentenced Jesus to death by crucifixion.
So the soldiers led Jesus away to crucify him. And Jesus was carrying his own cross.
Along the way, the soldiers forced a man named Simon to carry Jesus’ cross.
They came to a place called Golgotha, which means “Place of a Skull”. It was 9 o’clock in the morning when they nailed Jesus to a cross with iron spikes in his hands and his feet.
Looking down at those who had crucified him, Jesus said from the cross, “Father forgive them for they do not know what they are doing.”
Then Pilate’s soldiers gambled for Jesus’ clothes, fulfilling the Scripture that said, “They divided my garments among them, and gambled for my clothing.”
They fastened a sign on the cross above Jesus’ head written in Aramaic, Latin, and Greek. The sign said, “This is Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews.”
Two criminals also were crucified, one on each side of Jesus.
The people who passed by shook their heads and insulted Jesus. They said to him, “You claimed you would destroy the temple and build it again in three days. If you could do that, then rescue yourself by coming down from the cross!"
The chief priests and teachers of the Law also mocked Jesus. They said, “He saved others, but he cannot save himself! If he is the king of the Jews, he should come down now from the cross! Then we will believe him!"
One of the criminals being crucified began to insult Jesus, saying mockingly, “If you are the Messiah, then save yourself and us!”
But the other criminal stopped him by saying: “You should fear God. You and I deserve punishment. But this man, Jesus, has done nothing wrong.”
Then he said to Jesus, “Remember me when you begin ruling as king.”
Jesus answered him, “I tell you the truth, today you will be with me in paradise.”
At about noon, it became dark over the whole land.
After about three hours of darkness, Jesus shouted out loudly, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”
Soon after that, Jesus said, “I thirst.” One of the soldiers put vinegar on a sponge and offered it to him.
Then Jesus shouted, “It is finished.” and cried out “Father, into your hands I commit my spirit.” Then Jesus bowed his head, released his spirit, and died.
At that moment, the curtain of the Jewish temple was torn in two pieces from the top to the bottom.
And the earth shook, rocks split and graves opened. And many of God’s people came out of their graves and were later seen by many people.
When the captain of the Roman guard saw all that happened, he exclaimed, “Truly, this man was the Son of God!” The crowds went home in great sorrow.
The Jews asked Pilate to have soldiers break the legs of those crucified to insure they were dead. Then they could take away the bodies before the Passover Sabbath began.
So the soldiers broke the legs of the two criminals. When they came to Jesus, they saw he was dead, so they did not break his legs. But one soldier jabbed a spear into Jesus’ side. Immediately blood and water flowed out.
Jesus’ friends, including many women who had come with Jesus from Galilee to Jerusalem, were watching from a distance. These and others witnessed these events, and they were written down so that you also may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that by believing in him, you may have eternal life.

148 La crucifixion de Jésus





Le gouverneur romain Pilate croit que Jésus est innocent. Mais pour apaiser les chefs religieux et pour éviter que la foule ne se révolte, Pilate condamne Jésus à mourir sur une croix.
Alors les soldats emmènent Jésus pour le clouer sur une croix. Jésus porte sa propre croix.
Mais les soldats obligent un homme de Cyrène, appelé Simon, à porter la croix de Jésus.
Ils arrivent à un endroit appelé « le Crâne ». Ils clouent les mains et les pieds de Jésus sur la croix avec des pointes en fer et lèvent la croix. Il est environ neuf heures du matin.
Cloué à la croix, Jésus dit : « Père, pardonne-leur, ils ne savent pas ce qu’ils font. »
Les soldats tirent au sort pour savoir qui aura les vêtements de Jésus. Ainsi, ce qui est écrit dans les Ecritures se réalise : « Ils se sont partagé mes habits et ils ont tiré au sort mon vêtement. »
Sur la croix, au-dessus de la tête de Jésus, ils attachent une pancarte écrite en araméen, en latin et en grec qui indique pourquoi il est condamné. Elle porte l’inscription : « C’est Jésus, le roi des Juifs ».
Les soldats clouent aussi deux bandits sur des croix, un de chaque côté de Jésus.
Les gens qui passent par-là secouent la tête et ils insultent Jésus. Ils lui disent : « Tu voulais détruire le temple et en construire un autre en trois jours. Eh bien, sauve-toi toi-même et descends de la croix ! »
Les chefs des sacrificateurs et les maîtres de la loi se moquent aussi de lui. Ils disent : « Il a sauvé les autres, mais il ne peut pas se sauver lui-même ! S’il est le roi des Juifs, qu’il descende de la croix ! Alors nous croirons en lui. »
Un des bandits cloués sur une croix insulte Jésus en disant d’un ton moqueur : « Si tu es le Messie, sauve-toi toi-même et sauve-nous aussi ! »
Mais le deuxième bandit fait des reproches au premier en lui disant : « Tu devrais craindre Dieu. Toi et moi, nous méritons notre punition. Mais ce Jésus n’a rien fait de mal. »
Ensuite il dit à Jésus : « Souviens-toi de moi quand tu entreras dans ton royaume. »
Jésus lui répond : « Je te le dis, c’est la vérité : aujourd’hui, tu seras avec moi dans le paradis. »
A partir de midi, il fait nuit dans tout le pays parce que le soleil est obscurci.
Après trois heures d’obscurité, Jésus crie très fort : « Mon Dieu, mon Dieu, pourquoi m’as-tu abandonné? »
Peu après, pour accomplir les Ecritures, Jésus dit : « J’ai soif. » Un des soldats trempe une éponge dans du vinaigre et l’offre à Jésus.
Ensuite Jésus dit : « Tout est fini. » Puis il pousse un grand cri, il dit : « Père, je remets mon esprit dans tes mains. » Alors il baisse la tête et meurt.
A ce moment-là, le grand rideau qui est dans le temple à Jérusalem se déchire en deux morceaux, depuis le haut jusqu’en bas.
La terre tremble, les rochers se fendent et les tombes s’ouvrent. Beaucoup d’hommes et de femmes de Dieu qui étaient morts sortent de leur tombes et se montrent par la suite à beaucoup de gens.
Quand le capitaine des soldats romains qui gardent Jésus voie ce qui arrive, il dit : « Vraiment, cet homme était le Fils de Dieu ! » Alors les gens rentrent chez eux, se frappant la poitrine de tristesse.
Les chefs des Juifs demandent à Pilate d’ordonner à ses soldats de casser les jambes des crucifiés pour qu’ils meurent plus rapidement. Ainsi leurs corps pourraient être enlevés avant le début du sabbat de la Fête de la Pâque.
Alors les soldats cassent les jambes des deux bandits. Quand ils arrivent auprès de Jésus, ils voient qu’il est déjà mort. Alors ils ne lui cassent pas les jambes. Mais un des soldats perce le côté de Jésus avec sa lance. Du sang et de l’eau en sortent aussitôt.
Les amis de Jésus, y compris beaucoup de femmes qui ont accompagné Jésus depuis la Galilée jusqu’à Jérusalem, regardent de loin. Ces amis et beaucoup d’autres sont témoins de ces évènements et les mettent par écrit afin que vous aussi, vous puissiez croire.

019 The Plagues in Egypt.text:
019 The Plagues in Egypt

Exodus 7:3-12:29

019 The Plagues in Egypt

God sent Moses and Aaron to tell Pharaoh to release his people. But God made Pharaoh stubborn and Pharaoh refused. So God began to send plagues.
First the Lord made the Nile River water become blood. The fish died. The water stank, and the Egyptians could not drink the water.
Then the Lord made frogs come out of the waters of Egypt and cover the land.
Then the Lord infested the land with gnats, covering all the people and animals.
But just as God had said, Pharaoh still would not let the Israelites go out to the desert to worship God.
So, the Lord sent swarms of flies into Pharaoh's palace. They also filled the houses of his officials and covered the land.
But the Lord did not allow the flies to go into the region of Goshen where the Israelites were living.
Then Pharaoh told Moses, “I will let your people offer sacrifices; but you must not leave Egypt.”
Moses replied, “We must go into the wilderness as God commanded us.”
Pharaoh agreed, so Moses prayed and all the flies left.
But when the flies were gone, Pharaoh again became stubborn and refused to let the Israelites go.
So the Lord sent a deadly plague on all the Egyptians’ animals. Their horses, donkeys, camels, cattle, sheep and goats died.
But the animals of the Israelites didn’t die.
But Pharaoh was still stubborn and he would not let the Israelites go.
After that, the Lord told Moses to throw a few handfuls of ashes into the air. Moses did, and the ashes spread like dust over all Egypt. Then painful boils broke out on all the Egyptians and their animals.
But the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn and he would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said he would.
Then the Lord sent another plague. There was terrible thunder, hail and lightning. It was the most terrible hailstorm that Egypt had ever experienced!
The hail struck down every living thing out in the fields. It destroyed all the plants and stripped all the leaves from every tree.
But there was no hail where the Israelites lived in the region of Goshen.
This time Pharaoh asked Moses to pray that the hail would stop.
So Moses left the city, spread his hands toward the Lord and prayed, and the hail stopped.
Moses prayed this way so that Pharaoh would know that the earth belongs to the Lord.
But Pharaoh sinned again and became stubborn. He would not let the Israelites go.
The Lord told Moses, “Go, warn Pharaoh again. Tell him if he does not let the Israelites go, I will send locusts to swarm the land and eat everything the hail did not destroy. Then everyone will know that I am the Lord.”
When Pharaoh’s officials heard about this plague, they were afraid. They urged Pharaoh, saying, “This man is destroying Egypt. Let the Israelite men go worship the Lord, their god.”
Pharaoh told Moses and Aaron that only the Israelite men could go worship their god. Pharaoh refused to let the Israelite women and children go.
Then he angrily sent Moses and Aaron out of his palace.
Then the Lord caused a strong east wind to blow great swarms of locusts into Egypt. The swarms of locusts covered the ground so that the ground appeared black.
The locusts ate everything the hail had not destroyed. Then there were no green plants left in all of Egypt!
Then Pharaoh quickly called Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your god and against you. Forgive me, and ask the Lord to take away the deadly plague of locusts.”
So Moses left Pharaoh’s palace and prayed. Then the Lord sent a strong west wind that blew the locusts out of Egypt into the sea.
But the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn again. And again Pharaoh refused to let the Israelite people go.
The Lord told Moses to raise his hand toward the sky so there would be a plague of deep darkness. So Moses did that.
For three days and nights the Lord caused it to be completely dark throughout all of Egypt. The Egyptians could not see each other and none of them left their house during the darkness.
But, in the area where the Israelites lived, there was light.
Pharaoh told Moses, “You may go and worship God. Your wives and children may also go. But your sheep, goats and cattle must stay here.”
Moses answered, “No, you must let us take all our animals with us.”
“We will need animals to worship the Lord, our God. We will not know which animals to sacrifice until we get to the place where we are going.”
But God made Pharaoh stubborn again. Then Pharaoh said, “Get out of my sight, Moses!”
“Don’t let me ever see you again! On the day I do, you will die!”
Moses replied, “You are correct! You will never see me again.” Then he told Pharaoh, “This is what the Lord says:
“‘About midnight I will go through the land of Egypt. And every firstborn Egyptian son will die. Then you will know that I, the Lord, distinguish between my people and the Egyptians.’”
Moses also said, “When this happens, your officials will come to me and bow down in submission and beg me to take all the Israelites and leave Egypt. Then we will leave Egypt.” After that, Moses was very angry and left Pharaoh.
God told Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that the Egyptians will see even more mighty miracles.”
Then the Lord had said to Moses, “I will send only one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that, Pharaoh will let you go. When he does, he will force you to go.”
The Lord gave Moses and Aaron instructions for the people in preparation to leave Egypt.
So the Israelites prepared to leave Egypt according to the instructions the Lord gave Moses and Aaron. Each family killed an unblemished lamb or a young goat to eat at a special meal, the Lord’s Passover.
Each household leader took some of the blood from the Passover lamb or goat and smeared it on the doorposts of his house because the Lord had said, “When I see the blood, I will pass over you.”
Each family roasted its lamb or young goat and ate it that night with bitter herbs and bread without yeast. They ate quickly, with their clothes and shoes on, ready to leave Egypt.
At midnight the Lord killed all the firstborn sons of the Egyptians, even the firstborn son of Pharaoh. In this way God brought judgment on all the false gods of Egypt and proved that He alone was the one true God.
But when the Lord saw the blood on the doorposts of the homes of his people, he did not allow the destroyer to enter those homes and kill their firstborn sons.
The Lord commanded the Israelites to celebrate “Passover” as a festival every year to remember the night God “passed over” the homes marked with the blood.

019 Les Fléaux en Égypte



019 Les Fléaux en Égypte





Dieu a envoyé Moïse et Aaron devant Pharaon pour lui dire de laisser partir son peuple. Mais Dieu avait rendu Pharaon obstiné et Pharaon a refusé. Donc Dieu a commencé à envoyer des fléaux.
Tout d’abord, le Seigneur a causé l’eau du Nil de devenir du sang. Les poissons ont péri. L’eau puait et les Égyptiens ne pouvaient pas boire l’eau.
Ensuite le Seigneur a fait venir des grenouilles hors des eaux d’Égypte et elles ont couvert le pays.
Puis le Seigneur a infesté le pays avec des moucherons qui ont couvert les gens et les animaux.
Mais comme Dieu l’avait dit, le pharaon a encore refusé de laisser aller les Israelites dans le désert pour servir Dieu.
Donc le Seigneur a envoyé des nuées de mouches venimeuses dans le palais de Pharaon. elles ont aussi rempli les maisons de ses fonctionnaires et ont couvert le pays.
Mais le Seigneur n'a pas permis aux mouches d'aller dans la région de Gosen où les Israélites vivaient.
Alors Pharaon dit à Moïse: « Je vais laisser votre peuple offrir des sacrifices; mais vous ne devez pas quitter l'Égypte ».
Moïse a répliqué, « Nous devons aller dans le désert comme Dieu nous l’a commandé »
Pharaon a accepté, donc Moïse a prié et toutes les mouches sont parties.
Mais quand les mouches se sont éloignées, Pharaon est devenu de nouveau obstiné et il a refusé de laisser partir les Israelites.
Alors le Seigneur a envoyé un fléau mortel sur tous les animaux des Égyptiens. Leurs chevaux, ânes, chameaux, bovins, moutons et chèvres sont morts.
Mais les animaux des Israélites n’ont pas été ravagés.
Mais toujours le pharaon était obstiné et ne voulait pas laisser partir les Israelites.
Alors le Seigneur dit à Moïse de jeter des poignées de cendres dans l'air. Moïse a fait cela, et les cendres se sont répandues comme de la poussière sur toute l'Égypte. Puis des furoncles douloureux ont éclaté sur tous les Égyptiens et leurs animaux.
Mais le Seigneur avait rendu Pharaon obstiné et il ne voulait pas écouter Moïse et Aaron, exactement comme Le Seigneur l’avait prédit.
Alors le Seigneur a envoyé un autre fléau. Il y avait du tonnerre épouvantable, de la grêle et la foudre. Ce fut l’orage de grêle le plus terrible que l’Égypte n’avait jamais connu!
La grêle frappa tous les gens et les animaux dans les champs. Elle a détruit toutes les plantes et dépouillé toutes les feuilles de tous les arbres.
Mais il n'y avait pas de grêle où les Israélites vivaient dans la région de Gosen.
Cette fois Pharaon a demandé à Moïse de prier que la grêle s’arrête.
Moïse est sorti de la ville, a étendu ses mains vers le Seigneur et a prié, et la grêle s’est arrêtée.
Moïse a prié de cette façon pour faire savoir à Pharaon que la terre appartient au Seigneur.
Mais Pharaon a péché de nouveau et est redevenu obstiné. Il ne laisserait pas aller les Israélites.
Le Seigneur dit à Moïse: « Va, avertis Pharaon une fois de plus. Dis-lui que s'il ne laisse pas aller les Israélites, je vais envoyer des sauterelles qui vont grouiller sur la terre et manger tout ce que la grêle n'a pas détruit. Alors, tout le monde saura que je suis le Seigneur ».
Lorsque les fonctionnaires de Pharaon ont entendu parler de ce fléau, ils ont eu peur. Ils ont exhorté Pharaon, lui disant: « Cet homme est en train de détruire l'Égypte. Laissez aller les hommes d'Israël qu’ils adorent le Seigneur, leur Dieu ».
Pharaon dit à Moïse et à Aaron que les hommes d'Israël pouvaient aller adorer leur dieu. Mais il a refusé de laisser aller les femmes et les enfants d'Israël.
Et puis, en colère, il a envoyé Moïse et Aaron hors de son palais.
Alors le Seigneur a causé un vent puissant de l'est qui a poussé de larges multitudes de sauterelles sur le pays d’Égypte. Les multitudes de sauterelles ont couvert le sol de sorte que le sol a été obscurci.
Elles ont mangé tout ce que la grêle n’avait pas détruit. Donc, elles n’ont pas laissé de plantes vertes dans toute l'Égypte!
Pharaon a vite appelé Moïse et Aaron, et leur a dit: « J'ai péché contre le Seigneur votre Dieu et contre vous. Pardonnez-moi, et demandez au Seigneur d'enlever le fléau mortel des sauterelles ».
Alors Moïse est sorti du palais de Pharaon et a prié. Et le Seigneur a envoyé un vent très fort qui a poussé les sauterelles hors du pays d’Égypte et dans la mer.
Mais encore une fois de plus, le Seigneur avait rendu Pharaon obstiné. Et de nouveau Pharaon a refusé de laisser Israël partir.
Le Seigneur a dit à Moïse de lever ses mains au ciel pour qu’il y ait des ténèbres épaisses sur toute l’Égypte.
Pendant trois jours et trois nuits le Seigneur a causé que ce soit complètement sombre dans toute l'Égypte. Les Égyptiens ne pouvaient rien voir. Personne n’a quitté sa maison pendant ce temps de ténèbres.
Mais il y avait de la lumière partout où les Israelites vivaient.
Pharaon a fait chercher Moïse et a dit: « Vous pouvez aller adorer le Seigneur. Vos femmes et les enfants peuvent aussi aller. Mais tous vos animaux doivent rester ici. »
Moïse a répondu, « Vous devez nous laisser prendre tous nos animaux avec nous. »
« Nous aurons besoin des animaux pour adorer le Seigneur, notre Dieu. Nous ne saurons pas lesquels des animaux nous allons sacrifier jusqu'à ce que nous arrivons où nous allons ».
Mais de nouveau, le Seigneur avait rendu Pharaon obstiné. Et Pharaon a dit, « Fuis de devant ma face, Moïse »
« Ne me laisse jamais te voir ici! Le jour où je te vois, tu vas mourir! »
Moïse a répondu: « Vous avez raison! Vous ne me verrez plus. » Puis il dit à Pharaon: « Voici ce que dit le Seigneur: »
« Vers minuit, je vais parcourir le pays d'Égypte. Et chaque premier-né égyptien va mourir. Alors, vous saurez que moi, le Seigneur, je fais la distinction entre mon peuple et les Égyptiens. »
Moïse a dit: « Quand ça se passera, vos fonctionnaires viendront devant moi et se prosterneront en soumission et me supplieront de prendre tous les Israélites et de sortir d'Égypte. Alors, nous allons partir d'Égypte. » Moïse était très en colère et il est sorti de la présence de Pharaon.
Dieu dit à Moïse, « Pharaon ne vous écoutera pas, afin que les Égyptiens voient encore de plus puissants miracles. »
Ensuite le Seigneur dit à Moïse: « Je vais envoyer seulement un fléau de plus sur Pharaon et l'Égypte. Après cela, Pharaon vous laissera aller. Quand il le fera, il va vous forcer de partir. »
Alors le Seigneur a donné des instructions à Moise et à Aaron pour préparer le peuple à sortir d’Égypte.
Les Israélites se sont préparés à quitter l'Égypte selon les instructions données par le Seigneur à Moïse et Aaron. Chaque famille a tué un agneau sans défaut ou une jeune chèvre qui sera mangé à un repas spécial, la Pâque de l’Éternel.
L’ancien de chaque famille a pris le sang de la jeune chèvre ou de l’agneau et l’a mis sur le linteau et les deux montants de la porte de sa maison parce que le Seigneur avait dit: «Quand je verrai le sang, je passerai par-dessus vous. »
Chaque famille a rôti son agneau ou son chevreau et l’a mangé cette nuit avec des herbes amères et du pain sans levure. Ils ont mangé rapidement, vêtu de leurs vêtements et chaussures, prêt à sortir d'Égypte.
À minuit, le Seigneur a tué tous les premiers-nés des Égyptiens, même le fils premier-né de Pharaon. De cette façon, Dieu a apporté un jugement sur tous les faux dieux d'Égypte et a prouvé que Lui seul était l'unique vrai Dieu.
Mais quand le Seigneur a vu le sang sur le linteau et les montants de porte des maisons de son peuple, il n’a pas permis au destructeur d'entrer dans ces maisons et de tuer leurs premiers-nés.
Le Seigneur a commandé aux Israélites de célébrer la «Pâque» comme un festival chaque année pour se souvenir de la nuit quand Dieu « a passé sur » les maisons marquées avec le sang.

Animals Are Kind
Animals Are Kind



Once upon a time, there lived a farmer. He never liked birds as he believed that they will ruin his crop.
                                The farmer always used to stone the birds at sight.
But the farmer's only son, Sanju was quite
                                opposite to him. He loved birds and would feed
                                them. Farmer used to scold Sanju for this but
                                Sanju never stopped feeding the birds.
One day, while going to school, Sanju slipped and fell off. He was injured and could not walk for long. No one was around him to help.
A bird saw Sanju and understood that Sanju was having trouble. The bird remembered Sanju helping him. So he also decided to help Sanju.
The bird went back to farmer's house and started making a big noise.
This irritated the farmer. So the farmer started chasing the bird until he found Sanju lying on the ground helpless.
Farmer at once took Sanju to hospital. Sanju then explained everything to his father. Father felt ashamed for his rude behavior. Thereafter he too started liking animals and birds.

Content Objective: The pupils will be able to: •    recognize the dry and rainy seasons in their environment and the various activities carried out in each.

During the dry season it is sunny everyday.

During the rainy season it rains every day.

 During the dry season the soil is dry.

During the rainy season the soil is wet.

During the dry season the streams disappear.

During the rainy season the streams reappear.

During the dry season the cattle go down to the valley.

During the rainy season the cattle move out from the valleys.

During the dry season people plough the soil.

During rainy season people harvest corn.

Crocodile in My Body



     Hello, I’m Ntombi. I’m a little girl like other little girls, except...I have a crocodile in my body.
     You can’t see him, but I know he is there.  His name is Horrible InVader. He hides in my body and doesn’t do any harm to my friends.
     He won’t leave my body and go into yours if you sit next to me, or hold my hand.
     He won’t leave my body and jump into yours even if you share your lunch with me, or if we lie down on the floor togeth- er when we have a rest.
     My crocodile, Horrible InVader, has been with me since I was born.  He likes eating all the soldiers in my body that fight germs and stop me from getting sick.
     When he eats too many of my sold- iers, I get very sick. Then I cannot go to school and play with my friends.
      I have to take my medicine every day at the same time. Otherwise my croco- dile wakes up in a bad mood and eats my soldiers again.  I don’t want him to do that, so I remind my Gogo to give me my special medicine right on time.


     If I eat good food like vege- tables and fruit, the soldiers in my body get stronger and don't let my crocodile catch them.  I think he goes to sleep

for awhile, because then I am well and strong and able to play with my friends again.

       I am so happy when he goes to sleep and I am able to play.

     My Gogo took me to the clinic awhile
ago and got something special to feed my crocodile.  It makes him go to sleep, and he doesn't eat my soldiers.   Then I am able to do all the fun things that other children do, like run and climb and dance.
     I love my Gogo very much.  She is good and kind to me.  She gives me good food to eat and sees that I take extra vitamins, as well, to keep my soldiers strong, so that I don’t get sick.  If I do get sick, she takes me to the clinic right away, so that I can get medicine to make me better.
     I love it when she puts me on her lap and reads stories to me before I go to bed.
     After Gogo has put me to bed, I think of many things.  I think about learning to read at big school.  If I keep taking my special medicine that puts my crocodile to sleep, I will look after my Gogo and read her stories when she is very old and can’t see so well anymore.
     When I am a grown woman, I would like to study.  I want to help to find a medicine that will put all the crocodiles in other peoples’ bodies, to sleep for ever.
     I will learn to live with my crocodile and keep him asleep as much as I can.  I will have as many friends as I can.  And have as much fun as I can every day.
     My Gogo, my aunts and uncles, and friends love me, even though I have a crocodile called Horrible InVader living in my body.

The disciples had prepared everything for the Passover meal as Jesus told them.
As they were eating, Jesus got up from the dinner, took off his outer clothing and wrapped a towel around his waist.
He poured some water into a basin and began to wash the disciples’ feet, drying them with the towel that was around his waist.
Jesus came to Simon Peter, who said to him, “Lord, are you going to wash my feet?” Jesus replied to him, “If I do not wash you, then you have nothing to do with me.”
So Simon Peter said to him, “Lord, wash not only my feet! Wash my hands and my head also!” Jesus said to him, “One who has taken a bath needs only to wash his feet. The rest of his body is already clean.”
After he finished washing their feet, Jesus put his outer clothing on again. Then he sat down at his place again and asked, “Do you understand what I have done for you?”
“You call me ‘Teacher’ and ‘Lord.’ You are right to say this, for that is what I am. If I, your teacher and Lord, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another’s feet. I have given you an example to follow.”
“A servant is not greater than his master, nor is a messenger greater than the one who has sent him. If you know these things, how fortunate you will be if you do them.”
During the meal, Jesus said, “I tell you the truth, one of you here will betray me.” The disciples looked at one another, confused as to which one of them Jesus was talking about. Jesus said, “It is the one to whom I will give this bread.”
Then Jesus gave a piece of bread to Judas Iscariot. After receiving the bread, Judas went immediately out into the night. No one else knew why Jesus had done this.
As they were eating, Jesus took some bread and thanked God for it. He broke it in pieces and gave it to the disciples, saying, “Take this and eat it for this is my body.”
Then Jesus took the cup of wine and thanked God for it. He gave it to the disciples and they all drank from it. “This is my blood,” Jesus explained, “which confirms the new agreement God makes with his people. It is poured out as a sacrifice for many.”
“I will not drink wine again until the day I drink it new with you in my Father’s kingdom.”

Les disciples ont préparé le repas de la Pâque comme Jésus le leur avait instruit. C’est le soir, et ils s’installent pour le repas.
Alors Jésus se lève. Il enlève son vêtement de dessus et il prend un linge pour le serrer autour de sa taille.
Ensuite, il verse de l’eau dans une cuvette. Il se met à laver les pieds de ses disciples et à les essuyer avec le linge qu’il a autour de la taille.
Il arrive près de Pierre, qui lui dit : « Seigneur, Tu ne me laveras jamais les pieds ! » Mais Jésus lui répond : « Si je ne te lave pas les pieds, tu ne pourras pas être avec moi. »
Pierre lui dit : « Alors, Seigneur, ne me lave pas seulement les pieds, mais aussi les mains et la tête ! » Jésus lui répond : « Celui qui s’est déjà baigné n’a plus besoin de se laver, sauf les pieds. »
Quand Jésus a fini de laver leurs pieds, il remet son vêtement et il s’assoit. Il leur demande : « Est-ce que vous comprenez ce que je vous ai fait ?
Vous m’appelez "Maître" et "Seigneur", et vous avez raison. Alors si moi, le Seigneur et le Maître, je vous ai lavé les pieds, vous aussi, vous devez aussi vous laver les pieds les uns aux autres. Je vous ai montré l’exemple.
Le serviteur n’est pas plus important que son maître, l’envoyé n’est pas plus important que celui qui l’envoie. Maintenant, vous savez tout cela. Vous serez heureux si vous le faites.
Pendant qu’ils sont en train de manger, Jésus dit : « L’un de vous va me livrer. » Les disciples se regardent les uns les autres, ils ne savent pas de qui Jésus veut parler. Jésus dit : « C’est celui à qui je vais donner ce morceau de pain. »
Jésus donne le morceau de pain à Judas Iscariote. Judas le prend, et aussitôt il se lève et sort de la maison. Les autres disciples ne comprennent pas pourquoi Judas est parti. Seul Jésus sait.
Pendant qu’ils mangent, Jésus prend du pain. Il remercie Dieu, partage le pain et le donne à ses disciples. Il dit : « Prenez et mangez, ceci est mon corps. »
Ensuite il prend une coupe de vin. Il remercie Dieu, il donne la coupe à ses disciples et ils en boivent tous. Et Jésus dit : « Ceci est mon sang, le sang de la nouvelle alliance que Dieu fait avec son peuple. Il est versé pour un grand nombre de gens.
Je ne boirai plus de ce vin jusqu’au jour où je le boirai nouveau dans le Royaume de Dieu. »

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Le coronavirus, aussi appelé COVID-19, est un nouveau virus. Il a été signalé pour la première fois en Chine le 31 décembre 2019. Il a des symptômes semblables à ceux de la grippe et peut entraîner la mort dans certains cas graves. Il est répandu dans de nombreux pays dans le monde entier. L’origine de la maladie n’est pas encore connue.


Personne âgée

Personne cardiaque ou souffrant de maladie
Personnes vulnérables
Les personnes de tous âges, y compris les enfants, peuvent être infectées par ce nouveau virus. Les personnes âgées et les personnes souffrant de maladies préexistantes (comme l’asthme, le diabète, les maladies cardiaques, l’hypertension artérielle) semblent plus susceptibles de tomber gravement malades à cause de ce virus.

- Toux sèche

Les symptômes
Les symptômes d'une infection au coronavirus ressemblent à ceux de la grippe : fièvre, toux sèche, douleurs musculaires, fatigue. Certains patients ont des douleurs, une congestion nasale, un écoulement nasal, des maux de gorge ou une diarrhée. Certaines personnes, bien qu’infectées, ne présentent aucun symptôme et se sentent bien. La plupart des personnes guérissent sans avoir besoin de traitement particulier.

Personne qui tousse
Transmission du coronavirus
Le COVID-19 est transmis par des personnes porteuses du virus. Quand un malade tousse ou éternue, il expulse des gouttelettes par le nez ou la bouche. Si une personne respire ces gouttelettes, elle peut être contaminée par le coronavirus. Si une personne touche un objet infecté par ces gouttelettes et si elle se touche ensuite les yeux, le nez ou la bouche, elle peut aussi être contaminée.




Comment se protéger ?
1. Eviter de se toucher les yeux, le nez, la bouche.

2. Se laver souvent les mains à l'eau courante et au savon. Ensuite les sécher avec une serviette propre.

3. Tousser et éternuer dans le creux de son bras.

4. Eviter de manger de la viande crue et de toucher des animaux vivants.




5. Garder une distance d'au moins un mètre avec une personne qui tousse ou qui éternue.

6. Eviter de se serrer la main. Se saluer par un signe de tête ou une salutation verbale.

7. Eviter les rassemblements.

8. Limiter ses déplacements.

9. Se tenir informé et vérifier la source de ses informations.
Que faire en cas de contamination ?

Several months passed after the angel spoke with Mary.
Around that time, the Emperor of Rome, Caesar Augustus, made an official order that everyone had to go to his ancestors’ hometown to be registered.
Since Joseph was a descendant of King David, he had to go to Bethlehem to be registered. So Joseph and Mary traveled from Nazareth to Bethlehem.
There was no guest room available for them in Bethlehem, so they had to stay where the animals slept. Then it was time for Mary’s baby to be born. Mary wrapped her baby with cloths and laid him down in a box where they fed cattle.
That night, while shepherds were guarding their sheep in fields nearby, an angel of the Lord appeared to them. A bright light of the Lord’s glory shone all around them. The shepherds were very afraid!
The angel said, “Do not be afraid! I have good news, which will benefit all people. Today, in the city of David, a baby has been born who will save you from your sins! He is the Messiah, the Lord! You will find this baby wrapped with cloths and placed in a feeding place for animals.”
The shepherds went quickly to Bethlehem. When they found the place where Mary and Joseph were staying, they saw the baby lying in a feeding place for animals.
The shepherds told everyone what the angels had told them about this child, and the people were amazed. Mary kept thinking about all these things and carefully remembered them.
Eight days later, it was the day when the baby was circumcised, and they gave him the name Jesus. This was the name the angel had told them.
Forty days after Jesus was born, Joseph and Mary traveled up to Jerusalem to dedicate their son to the Lord. The law of the Lord required a sacrifice of two turtledoves or two young pigeons.
When Joseph and Mary brought their baby, Jesus, to the temple, an old man named Simeon met them.
Simeon did what was pleasing to God and obeyed God’s laws, and he was eagerly waiting for the Messiah. The Holy Spirit had revealed to Simeon that he would see the Lord’s promised Messiah before he died.
Simeon took Jesus up in his arms and praised God, saying, “Lord, you have made me content and now I can die in peace according to your promise. I have seen the one whom you sent to save all people.”
Simeon said to Mary, “God has determined that because of this child, many people will turn away from God. Many others will turn to God.
Many people will be against him, and your own heart will be filled with sorrow.” Joseph and Mary were very amazed at Simeon’s words.

102 La naissance du Messie





Quelques mois ont passé depuis que l’ange a annoncé à Marie qu’elle va avoir un fils.
À cette époque, l’empereur de Rome nommé César Auguste donne l’ordre de compter les habitants de tous les pays. Tout le monde va se faire inscrire, chacun dans la ville de ses ancêtres.
Joseph prend Marie et quitte la ville de Nazareth pour aller à Bethléem. C’est la ville du roi David, l’ancêtre de Joseph.
Pendant qu’ils sont à Bethléem, le moment arrive où Marie doit accoucher. Il n’y a pas de place pour eux dans la salle pour les voyageurs, alors ils doivent dormir dans l’étable. Marie couche l’enfant nouveau-né dans une mangeoire.
Cette nuit-là, des bergers sont dans les champs pour garder leur troupeau. Un ange du Seigneur apparaît devant eux. La gloire du Seigneur enveloppe les bergers de lumière, et ils ont très peur.
L’ange leur dit : « N’ayez pas peur. En effet, je viens vous annoncer une bonne nouvelle qui sera une grande joie pour tous les peuples. Aujourd’hui, dans la ville de David, votre Sauveur est né. C’est le Christ, le Seigneur. Vous le trouverez enveloppé dans des langes et couché dans une mangeoire. »
Alors se dépêchent d’aller à Bethléem. Là, ils trouvent Marie et Joseph, et le petit enfant couché dans la mangeoire.
Les bergers leur racontent tout ce que l’ange leur a dit sur l’enfant tous ceux qui ont entendu les bergers sont étonnés !
Marie retient tout ce qui s’est passé, elle réfléchit à cela dans son cœur.
Huit jours après qu’il est né, Marie et Joseph vont faire circoncire l’enfant. C’est à ce moment-là qu’ils lui donnent le nom de Jésus. C’est le nom que l’ange leur a dit de lui donner.
Quarante jours après la naissance de Jésus, Joseph et Marie se rendent au temple de Dieu à Jérusalem pour présenter Jésus devant le Seigneur. Ils offrent aussi deux pigeons en sacrifice, comme la Loi du Seigneur le demande.
Pendant qu’ils sont au temple, un homme âgé nommé Siméon s’approche d’eux.
Siméon est un homme juste qui attend le Sauveur qui va venir au secours du peuple d’Israël. L’Esprit de Dieu a promis à Siméon qu’il ne mourra pas avant d’avoir vu le Sauveur, le Messie de Dieu.
Siméon prend Jésus dans ses bras et remercie Dieu en disant : « Seigneur, tu as tenu ta promesse. Maintenant, je peux mourir dans la paix. En effet, mes yeux ont vu le Sauveur, c’est lui que as envoyé pour tous les peuples. »
Ensuite Siméon dit à Marie : « Beaucoup d’Israélites vont rejeter cet enfant. Mais il sera aussi le Sauveur et la plus grande joie pour beaucoup d’autres.
Beaucoup de gens le rejetteront. Et toi, Marie, la souffrance te va te transpercer comme une lance. »
Marie et Joseph sont étonnés par ces mots.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

7. Avoid gatherings.


8. Restrict movement.

9. Keep informed and verify the source of information.
What to do in case of contamination?
If you have symptoms:
- Avoid contact with other people.
- Stay at home.
- Call 1510 and follow the doctor's instructions. Other possible numbers:

Personnes vulnérables
Les personnes de tous âges, y compris les enfants, peuvent être infectées par ce nouveau virus. Les personnes âgées et les personnes souffrant de maladies préexistantes (comme l’asthme, le diabète, les maladies cardiaques, l’hypertension artérielle) semblent plus susceptibles de tomber gravement malades à cause de ce virus.

Transmission du coronavirus
Le COVID-19 est transmis par des personnes porteuses du virus. Quand un malade tousse ou éternue, il expulse des gouttelettes par le nez ou la bouche. Si une personne respire ces gouttelettes, elle peut être contaminée par le coronavirus. Si une personne touche un objet infecté par ces gouttelettes et si elle se touche ensuite les yeux, le nez ou la bouche, elle peut aussi être contaminée.

One day, Jesus was teaching many tax collectors and other sinners who had gathered to hear him.
Some religious leaders who were also there saw Jesus treating these sinners as friends, and they began to criticize him to each other. So Jesus told them this story.
“There was a man who had two sons. The younger son told his father, ‘Father, I want my inheritance now!’ So the father divided his property between his two sons.”
“Soon the younger son gathered all that he had and went far away and wasted his money in sinful living.”
“After that, a severe famine happened in the land where the younger son was, and he had no money to buy food. So he took the only job he could find, feeding pigs. He was so miserable and hungry that he wanted to eat the pigs’ food.”
“Finally, the younger son said to himself, ‘What am I doing? All my father’s servants have plenty to eat, and yet here I am starving. I will go back to my father and ask to be one of his servants.’”
“So the younger son started back towards his father’s home. When he was still far away, his father saw him and felt compassion for him. He ran to his son and hugged him and kissed him.”
“The son said, ‘Father, I have sinned against God and against you. I am not worthy to be your son.’”
“But his father told one of his servants, ‘Go quickly and bring the best clothes and put them on my son! Put a ring on his finger and put sandals on his feet. Then kill the best calf so we can have a feast and celebrate, because my son was dead, but now he is alive! He was lost, but now he is found!’”
“So the people began to celebrate. Before long, the older son came home from working in the field. He heard the music and dancing and wondered what was happening.”
“When the older son found out that they were celebrating because his brother had come home, he was very angry and would not go into the house. His father came out and begged him to come and celebrate with them, but he refused.”
“The older son said to his father, ‘All these years I have worked faithfully for you! I never disobeyed you, and still you did not even give me one small goat so I could celebrate with my friends. But when this son of yours who consumed your money in sinful behavior came home, you killed the best calf for him!’”
“The father answered, ‘My son, you are always with me, and everything I have is yours. But it is right for us to celebrate, because your brother was dead, but now is alive. He was lost, but now is found!’”

35. La Parabole du Fils prodigue





Un jour, Jésus enseignait beaucoup de collecteurs d’impots et de pécheurs qui s’étaient rassemblés pour l’écouter.
Certains des chefs religieux qui étaient présents se plaignaient de ce que Jésus traitait les publicains et les pécheurs comme desamis, et ils commencèrent à le critiquer . Alors, Jésus leur dit cette parabole:
“Un homme avait deux fils. Le plus jeune dit à son père: ’Père, donne-moi maintenant la part de bien qui doit me revenir! ’Alors le père partagea ses biens entre ses deux fils.”
“Peu de jours après, le plus jeune fils, ayant tout ramassé, partit dans un pays éloigné où il dépensa tout son bien en vivant dans la débauche.”
“Après cela, une grande famine survint dans le pays où le plus jeune fils habitait, et il n’eut plus d’argent pour s’acheter à manger. Et il se mit au service d’un habitant du pays, qui l’envoya dans ses champs garder son troupeau de cochons. Il eut tellement faim qu’il voulut manger ce que mangeaient les cochons.”
“Le plus jeune fils se dit:”‘Combien de serviteurs chez mon père ont du pain en abondance, et moi, ici je meurs de faim! Je retournerai vers mon père lui demanderai pardon et qu’il m’accepte comme l’un de ses serviteurs.’"
"Alors, le plus jeune fils se mit en route pour la maison de son père. Quand il était encore loin, son père le vit et fut ému de compassion. Il courut se jeter à son cou et l’embrassa."
“Le fils lui dit: ‘Père, j’ai péché contre Dieu et contre toi. Je ne suis pas digne d’être appelé ton fils.’”
“Mais son père dit à un de ses serviteurs: ‘Apportez vite le plus beau vêtement et mettez-le lui! Mettez-lui un anneau au doigt et des chaussures à ses pieds. Puis amenez le veau gras, et tuez-le. Mangeons et réjouissons-nous parce que mon fils était mort et il est revenu à la vie!’”
“Alors les gens commencèrent à se réjouir. Peu après, le fils ainé qui travaillait dans les champs, rentra et en approchant de la maison, il entendit la musique et les danses et se demanda ce qui se passait.”
“Quand le fils ainé découvrit qu’il y avait une fête parce que son frère était revenu, il se mit en colère et ne voulut pas entrer. Son père sortit et le pria de venir se réjouir avec eux, mais il refusa.”
“Le fils aîné dit à son père:”Voici, il y a tant d’années que je te sers sans avoir jamais transgressé tes ordres, et jamais tu ne m’as donné un chevreau pour me réjouir avec mes amis. Mais quand ton fils est rentré, celui qui a depensé ton bien par une conduite scandaleuse, c’est pour lui que tu as tué le veau gras!’"
“Le père répondit: ‘Mon fils, tu es toujours avec moi, et tout ce que j’ai est à toi. Mais il fallait bien se réjouir, parce que ton frère était mort et maintenant il est revenu à la vie. Il était perdu et il est retrouvé.’”

One day Fatima’s mother sent her to the market.  As Fatima was walking, she began to count the things that she saw along the way.




First Fatima saw one big, beautiful cow.  “Good morning, Mr. Cow,” said Fatima. The cow said, “Moo.”




Then Fatima saw two boys running by.  “Where are you going?” Fatima called, but they didn’t hear her.




Next Fatima saw three little kittens by the side of the road.  “Where is your mother?” asked Fatima, but they just scampered away.




Fatima saw four ripe mangoes hanging low on a branch.   Fatima declared, “Mmm, now I am feeling hungry.”




Later, Fatima passed five women pounding millet.  “Look how strong they are!” Fatima exclaimed.




Fatima laughed when she saw a boy trying to herd six goats.  “He does not have an easy job,” said Fatima.




Next Fatima noticed seven birds playing by a bush.  “I wish I could fly like you!” said Fatima with a sigh.




Fatima passed eight people talking under a tree.  “I wonder what they are talking about,” Fatima thought to herself.




Then Fatima came by a woman grilling maize. Fatima counted nine ears for sale.  “That smells delicious,” declared Fatima.




Finally, Fatima saw ten baby chicks pecking for food on the ground.  Fatima counted them out, “One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, and ten!”
On her way to market, Fatima counted many things from one to ten.  And so did you!
Check Your Understanding!  1. Where was Fatima going? 2. What did Fatima see first? 3. How many mangoes did Fatima count? 4. What did Fatima count seven of? 5. What was the last thing Fatima counted on her walk?

                        The pupils will be able to name opposites.
One man is tall.

Oral Comprehension Questions:
                        1.    What is the opposite of:  Open?  Tall?  Up?  Inside?  Sitting?
                        2.    Give other examples for the children to state the opposites:
                                For example:  good/bad, happy/sad, fast/slow, hot/cold, light/dark, on/under,
       clean/dirty, sick/healthy, full/empty, on/off, soft/hard, safe/dangerous
Possible Activities:
                        1.    Make a class book of opposites.  Assign opposite words to each child and have them illustrate the two words. The teacher should write the words for the children.
                        2.    Name opposites and have the children demonstrate them.
                        For example:  the children could sit on their desks and then under their desks.  Or a child could go outside and then come inside.
                        3.  Learning to Write a Sentence
                        •    Tell the class that you want someone to tell you an interesting sentence using opposites. Write the sentence with a marker on a cardboard strip exactly as the student dictated it.  Read it aloud as you write it, and then hold it up and read it to the children. Point out the capital letter at the beginning and the full stop at the end, with space between each word. 
                        •    Ask for one child to read the first word of the sentence.  With scissors cut off the first word only, and give it to the child who read it.  Have that child stand in front of the class and hold up the word for the children to read.  Continue this with all words in the sentence. 
                        •    Scramble the words of the sentence by rearranging the children who are at the front. Ask the students to build the sentence again.  What is the first word of the sentence?  How can they tell immediately, which is the first word of the sentence? (It begins with a capital letter.)  What is the last word of the sentence?  How can they tell? (It ends with a full stop.)

Questions orales de compréhension
                        1.    Quel est le contraire de grand, ouvert, dans le ciel, dedans, assis ?
                        2.    Donner aux enfants d’autres mots dont ils diront les contraires.
       Par exemple : bon/mauvais, content/triste, rapide/lent, chaud/froid, lumineux/sombre,
       dessus/dessous, propre/salle, malade/en bonne santé, plein/vide, allumé/éteint,
       doux/dur, sûr/dangereux
Activités possibles
                        1.    Faire un livre des contraires pour la classe. Donner deux mots contraires à chaque enfant et leur demander de les illustrer. Ecrire les mots pour chaque enfant.
                        2.    Citer des mots contraires et demander aux enfants de les mimer.
Par exemple, les enfants devraient s’asseoir sur leur bureau et sous leur bureau ou encore un enfant devrait aller à l’extérieur, puis revenir à l’intérieur.
                        3.  Apprendre à écrire une phrase
                        •    Dire à la classe que vous voulez que quelqu’un donne une phrase intéressante sur sa maison. Ecrire la phrase au feutre sur une bande cartonnée, telles que l’élève l’a dictée. La lire à haute voix en l’écrivant. Puis la montrer et la lire aux enfants. Leur signaler la majuscule du début et le point final ainsi que l’espace entre les mots.
                        •    Demander à un enfant de lire le premier mot de cette phrase. Avec des ciseaux, couper le premier mot et le donner à l’enfant qui l’a lu. Demander à cet enfant de venir devant et de montrer le mot aux enfants pour qu’ils le lisent. Faire de même pour tous les mots de la phrase.
                        •    Mélanger les mots de la phrase en déplaçant les enfants qui se tiennent devant leurs camarades. Demander aux élèves de remettre la phrase dans l’ordre. Quel est le premier mot de la phrase ? Comment peuvent-ils dire tout de suite quel est-il ? (Il commence par une majuscule.) Quel est le dernier mot de la phrase ? A quoi le voient-ils ? (Il se termine par un point.)

Math topic: Addition of 3-digit numbers
The Thousand Bags of Grain
Once there was a village called Dombo. The people of Dombo were honest and faithful, but they were also very poor and hungry.
One day, the village head, the elders, and the community decided to solve their problem of hunger.
“We must inspire our farmers to produce more food,” said the village head. “Let’s have a competition. Whoever can produce 1,000 bags of grain will be named farmer of the year.”
Many farmers agreed to do the competition. Malam Kowa said to himself, “I will work twice as hard as before, farming by hand. I will surely win.” Malam Nalado said to himself, “I will hire two strong men to help me. I will surely win.” But Malam Dankeke said to himself, "Let me see what the other villages have done.” So Malam Dankeke visited the neighboring villages. He saw the farmers there were using tractors, and producing hundreds of bags of grain. “Let me rent a tractor,” he said. “Perhaps I will win.”
Harvest season came. Malam Kowa had worked twice as hard as usual. He produced 200 bags of corn and 200 bags of millet.

Malam Nalado had hired two strong men. Together, they produced 300 bags of corn and 300 bags of millet. Malam Dankeke had used his tractors. He produced 500 bags of corn and 500 bags of millet.
“It is decided!” cried the village head. “Malam Dankeke is the winner!”

Reading Comprehension Questions
How many bags of corn and millet did Malam Dankeke produce?
Why do you think that Malam Dankeke’s strategy worked better than the others?
Do you think the village solved their problem of hunger?

Math Exercises
1) Write Malam Kowa’s name on the board. Then ask pupils how many bags of corn and how many bags of millet he grew. Then show pupils how to find the answer by adding the numbers on the board:  
  200﻿+200

2) Repeat step 1 with Malam Nalado (using 300 and 300) and Malam Dankeke (using 500 and 500). Ask for volunteers to add the numbers.
3) Ask pupils if Malam Kowa and Malam Nalado combined could match Malam Dankeke. Then show them how to add to find the answer with addition:
  400 ﻿+600

EXTENSION: Read the story again. When you arrive at the part when the bags are announced, ask volunteer pupils to add the totals again on the board.

Le coronavirus, aussi appelé COVID-19, est un nouveau virus. Il a été signalé pour la première fois en Chine le 31 décembre 2019. Il a des symptômes semblables à ceux de la grippe et peut entraîner la mort dans certains cas graves. Il est répandu dans de nombreux pays dans le monde entier. L’origine de la maladie n’est pas encore connue.

Personne âgée


Personne cardiaque ou souffrant de maladie
Personnes vulnérables
Les personnes de tous âges, y compris les enfants, peuvent être infectées par ce nouveau virus. Les personnes âgées et les personnes souffrant de maladies préexistantes (comme l’asthme, le diabète, les maladies cardiaques, l’hypertension artérielle) semblent plus susceptibles de tomber gravement malades à cause de ce virus.

- Fièvre
- Fatigue


- Toux sèche
- Douleurs musculaires
Les symptômes
Les symptômes d'une infection au coronavirus ressemblent à ceux de la grippe : fièvre, toux sèche, douleurs musculaires, fatigue. Certains patients ont des douleurs, une congestion nasale, un écoulement nasal, des maux de gorge ou une diarrhée. Certaines personnes, bien qu’infectées, ne présentent aucun symptôme et se sentent bien. La plupart des personnes guérissent sans avoir besoin de traitement particulier.


Personne qui tousse
Transmission du coronavirus
Le COVID-19 est transmis par des personnes porteuses du virus. Quand un malade tousse ou éternue, il expulse des gouttelettes par le nez ou la bouche. Si une personne respire ces gouttelettes, elle peut être contaminée par le coronavirus. Si une personne touche un objet infecté par ces gouttelettes et si elle se touche ensuite les yeux, le nez ou la bouche, elle peut aussi être contaminée.




Comment se protéger ?

1. Eviter de se toucher les yeux, le nez, la bouche.
2. Se laver souvent les mains à l'eau courante et au savon. Ensuite les sécher avec une serviette propre.



3. Tousser et éternuer dans le creux de son bras.

4. Eviter de manger de la viande crue et de toucher des animaux vivants.




5. Garder une distance d'au moins un mètre avec une personne qui tousse ou qui éternue.

6. Eviter de se serrer la main. Se saluer par un signe de tête ou une salutation verbale.

7. Eviter les rassemblements.

8. Limiter ses déplacements.

9. Se tenir informé et vérifier la source de ses informations.

Que faire en cas de contamination ?
Si vous présentez des symptômes :
- Evitez les contacts avec d'autres personnes.
- Restez à domicile.
- Appelez le 1510 et suivez les consignes des médecins. Autres numéros possibles :

699 279 622
675 308 373

A ce jour, il n'existe aucun médicament capable de guérir du COVID-19 mais les autorités continuent les recherches pour trouver un traitement adapté.
Chacun doit être responsable et adopter les bons gestes pour se protéger et protéger son entourage.

061 Elijah and the Widow of Zarephath


After King Solomon died, Rehoboam became king. Soon after he became king, the kingdom was divided. Jeroboam ruled the kingdom of Israel in the north and Rehoboam ruled the kingdom of Judah in the south.
Many years after the kingdom divided, a man named Ahab ruled as the king of Israel for twenty-two years. He reigned over Israel in Samaria. Ahab was more evil than any Israelite king who had ruled before him.
Ahab married a woman named Jezebel from a foreign country and started to worship her gods. He built a temple for the false god Baal in Samaria. He also set up a wooden pole for the worship of the goddess Asherah.
Then a prophet named Elijah went to King Ahab and said, “In the name of the Lord, the God of Israel whom I serve, I tell you that there will be no dew or rain during the next few years until I say so.”
God told Elijah to go to the brook Cherith and he did. There, just as God had promised, ravens brought him food every morning and evening. But soon the brook dried up, because there was no rain.
So God said to Elijah, “Go to the town of Zarephath, near Sidon, and stay there. I have told a widow who lives there to feed you.”
When Elijah arrived at the town gates of Zarephath, he saw a widow gathering sticks for firewood. He asked her, “Would you bring me a cup of water and a piece of bread, too?”
But she replied, “Your God knows that I do not have even one piece of bread in my house. I have only a handful of flour and a little jug of olive oil. With these sticks, I will make a fire and cook the last meal for my son and me. Then we will die from hunger.”
“Don’t worry,” Elijah said, “but first bake a small loaf of bread for me. God has promised that there will always be flour and oil left in your containers, until the time God sends the rain again.” The woman did exactly what Elijah told her to do, and they had enough food every day!
After some time passed, the widow's son became very sick. He continued to get worse, and finally he died. The woman said to the prophet Elijah, “Why have you done this to me?”
Elijah carried the boy upstairs to his own bed. Then he prayed aloud, “Oh, Lord, this poor widow has kindly allowed me to stay in her home. So why have you brought this tragedy and allowed her son to die?”
Then Elijah stretched himself out on the boy’s body three times and prayed, “0h Lord, please restore this child to life!”
The Lord answered Elijah's prayer and caused the child to breathe! Elijah carried the boy down and gave him to his mother alive again! The woman exclaimed, “Now I know that you are a prophet and the words you speak are truly from God!”

Anu sat up like a shot.
                                “Baby? Is it a teeny-tiny baby? Like a doll? Wait for me, I’m coming!”
Anu got ready in a jiffy.
                                She gulped down her milk without a fuss.
                                She didn't even cry when her mother combed her hair.
The moment Anu entered Aunty’s house she shouted, “Aunty! Where is the baby?”
                                “Shhhh...” said Aunty Jui, with her finger on her lips. “Softly. The baby is sleeping.”
                                Sleeping? What a bore. Anu began to sulk.
Aai pulled Anu close. “The baby is still very small, Anu. You must not trouble her.

                                “Oh no, Anu. You won’t be able to. You’re much too small,” said Aai.

Why should the baby sit on Aai’s lap? I want to sit on Aai’s lap too, thought Anu. But
                                Aai said, “Anu, move away! You must not bother baby. See how tiny she is?”
The baby was still wailing. “Waah...”
                                “Oh dear!” said Aunty. “I think she’s soiled her nappy.”
                                She cleaned the baby and changed her nappy.
                                The baby gurgled happily.
Anu was disgusted. What a silly baby. Potty in the nappy!
                                And Aai and Aunty were mad! They didn't even scold the baby.

                                is.

                                Anu muttered all the way home.

Coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, is a new virus. It was first reported in China on 31 December 2019. It has flu-like symptoms and can cause death in some severe cases. It is widespread in many countries around the world. The origin of the disease is not yet known.


Elderly person

Person with a heart condition or disease
Vulnerable people
People of all ages can become infected with this new virus. The elderly and people with pre-existing conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure) seem more likely to become seriously ill from this virus.


Fever
Fatigue

Dry cough
Muscle aches and pains
Symptoms
The symptoms of a coronavirus infection are similar to those of the flu: fever, dry cough, muscle aches, fatigue. Some patients have pain, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea. Some people, although infected, have no symptoms and feel fine. Most people recover without needing any special treatment.

Person with a cough
Transmission of coronavirus
COVID-19 is transmitted by people carrying the virus. When a sick person coughs or sneezes, they expel droplets through their nose or mouth. If a person breathes in these droplets, they can become infected with the coronavirus. If a person touches an object infected with these droplets and then touches their eyes, nose or mouth, they can also become infected.




How to protect yourself
1. Avoid touching eyes, nose, mouth.

2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and running water. Then dry them with a clean towel.

3. Cough and sneeze into the crook of your arm.


4. Avoid eating raw meat and touching live animals.




5. Keep at least one meter away from a person who is cou- ghing or sneezing.


6. Avoid shaking hands. Greet each other with a nod or a verbal greeting.

Math topic: Multiplication
Spider and the Many Legs
Lion was king of all the animals. He was also the custodian of the animals’ food chamber. He gave the most food to the large animals and the least food to the small. But one day, Spider, the smallest animal in the kingdom, decided she was tired of always receiving the least. She presented herself before the king.
“Oh great king,” she said. “I know that you are very wise, and yet you do not take what is due to you. You give more food to Elephant than you do to yourself, even though you are the king.”
Lion replied, “That is because Elephant is larger than me, and by law more food is due to him.”
“Then why not change the law?” Spider asked.
“Give food according to the number of legs. This way, at least you will receive the same as Elephant.”
Lion was impressed with Spider’s solution and changed the law. Soon, however, he realized the Spider had 8 legs while he only had 4. Therefore, Spider was receiving twice as much food. Lion summoned Spider again.
“Spider,” said Lion. “Do you really think it is fair that a spider should receive twice as much food as a lion?”
“That is true,” said Spider. “That is not fair. Perhaps you can change the law again. Provide food according to the number of legs in one family.”
Lion was impressed with Spider’s solution. Lion had one wife and three children, and therefore 20 legs in all. Meanwhile, Spider had no husband and no children, and therefore only 8 legs in all.

“Very well,” said Lion. “I will change the law. But I solemnly swear that is the last time, as laws should not be changed too often.” Thus Lion changed the law so that the most food would be given to the families with the most legs.
As soon as the law was passed, Spider promptly went to get married. Unknowingly to Lion, she went out and married Centipede, who had 100 legs. And from that day forward Spider and her husband received the most food in the kingdom, for together they had 108 legs.

Reading Comprehension Questions
How many legs does Spider have?﻿Why did Spider ask the Lion to change the law?﻿Who do you think was more clever, Spider or Lion? Why?

Math Exercises
1) Write down the names of everyone in Lion’s family. Then ask pupils how many legs each family member has and write it next to the name. Finally, ask a pupil to help you add them together. The result should look like this.
Lion               4
Lion’s wife    4
Lion Child     4
Lion Child     4
Lion Child  + 4

2) Explain that when we add the same number over and over again, multiplication can help us solve the problem more quickly. Ask pupils how many number 4s are written on the board. Pupils should say 5.
Then write: 4 X 5 = 20.

3) Ask pupils how many legs 5 humans would have. Then help pupils solve the problem with both repeated addition and multiplication.
2+2+2+2+2=
2 X 5 =

EXTENSION: Ask pupils how many legs 5 spiders would have. Use repeated addition (8+8+8+ 8+8) and multiplication (8X5).

Lion était le roi de tous les animaux. Il était aussi le gardien de la chambre de la nourriture pour tous les animaux. Il donnait plus de nourriture aux grands animaux et moins aux petits. Mais un jour, Araignée, la bête la plus petite du royaume, décida qu’elle en avait marre de toujours recevoir le moins. Elle se présenta alors devant le roi.
« Ô grand roi », dit-elle : « Je sais que tu es très sage, mais tu ne sais pas ce qui t’est dû. Tu donnes plus de nourriture à Éléphant que tu en prends pour toi, et le roi c’est toi. »
Lion répondit : « C’est parce qu’Éléphant est plus grand que moi et la loi dit qu’il doit recevoir plus de nourriture. »
« Mais pourquoi ne pas changer la loi ? » demanda Araignée.
« Donne de la nourriture d’après le nombre ﻿de pattes. Ainsi, tu auras au moins autant qu’Éléphant. » Lion, impressionné par la solution d’Araignée, changea la loi. Bientôt il réalisa qu’Araignée avait 8 pattes alors que ﻿lui n’en avait que 4. Du coup, Araignée en recevait le double de ce que recevait Lion. ﻿Il convoqua alors encore une fois Araignée.
« Araignée », dit Lion. « Penses-tu vraiment que c’est juste qu’une araignée reçoive deux fois la quantité de nourriture de celle pour un lion ? »
« C’est vrai », dit Araignée. « Ce n’est pas juste. Tu pourrais peut-être changer la loi encore une fois. Donne la nourriture d’après ﻿le nombre de pattes dans une famille. »
Lion était impressionné par la solution d’Araignée. Lion avait une femme et trois enfants, et donc 20 pattes au total. Par contre, Araignée n’avait ni mari ni enfant. ﻿Elle n’avait donc au total que 8 pattes.

« Très bien », dit Lion. « Je vais changer la loi. Mais comme les lois ne devraient pas être changées trop souvent, je jure solennellement que ce sera la dernière fois. »
Donc Lion changea la loi pour que le plus de nourriture soit donnée aux familles avec le plus grand nombre de pattes.
Aussitôt que la loi fut adoptée, Araignée alla se marier. Sans que Lion le sache, elle maria Mille-Pattes, qui avait 1 000 pattes. À partir de ce jour, c’était Araignée et son mari recevaient le plus de nourriture dans le royaume parce qu’ensemble, ils avaient 1 008 pattes.

How to make and use compost



How to make and use compost





To start a compost pile, look for a shady place under a tree or alongside a wall.
You also need boards. Stones or bricks may be used instead of boards.
Take the boards, bricks or stones and make an enclosed place under the tree or next to the wall.
Fill it with dead grass and weeds, leaves and kitchen leftovers.
Make a pile next to the compost pile of, for example, ashes, sawdust or soil, to cover up the compost. This will keep the flies away.
Do not put in glass, tins, paper, big sticks, plastic bags, and other things that cannot decompose quickly.
Water the compost during the dry season. The small insects and worms that cause decomposition need humidity to work. But be careful: if there is too much water, you will only get mud and not compost. If there is not enough water, you will only have mold and waste that will not decompose well.
After a few months the compost will be ready. Take the boards away and shovel the compost to the side, so that the top layer is on the bottom and the bottom layer is on the top. Let it sit for a few weeks before using it.
Put the boards back and fill the enclosed place again with dead grass, weeds, leaves and kitchen leftovers. You now have three piles: one freshly started pile in the enclosed place; a pile of sawdust, ashes or soil to cover up the compost; and a pile of compost that is almost ready.
Keep on adding to the new pile to make more compost. Add dead grass, kitchen leftovers, etc. until the enclosed place is almost full.
Cover the compost with some more soil, ashes and sawdust.
Then you will have more compost. The first pile is now ready to use.
If you have a big field, you can make a big pile.
How to use compost.
The compost is ready to use when it is dark and feels like soil, and when there are worms in it. Worms are very good for the soil.
In your garden place small heaps of compost on the ground. After that, put small mounds of soil on top.
When making furrows, put some compost in the furrows first. Then cover it with soil.

When you put the plants in the soil, you should first put some compost in the planting hole and then cover it with soil.
You do the same thing when you plant a tree.

When you have plenty of compost, you can spread it in the garden before digging it into the ground.




In the nursery, fill the seedboxes half full of compost and half full of good soil, then mix them together well.



The compost makes the plants grow very well.

So there will be enough food to eat and to sell at the market.
